Ending Violence God‚Äôs Way 16 Oct 2023 God‚Äôs promises are real and He calls upon us to understand that He is always willing to intervene in our world to help us and to bring healing, if we are ready to do what He asks. This is what God promises: ‚ÄúIf my people, who are called by my name, will humble themselves and pray and seek my face and turn from their wicked ways, then I will hear from heaven, and I will forgive their sin and will heal their land.‚Äù 2 Chronicles 7:14 We can influence the course of world events this very day, if we are ready to do three things: 1. We must have faith and believe that for God all things are possible. ‚ÄúAnd without faith it is impossible to please God, because anyone who comes to him must believe that he exists and that he rewards those who earnestly seek him.‚Äù Hebrews 11:6 2. We must repent of our sins and stop offending God. ‚ÄúIf we confess our sins, he is faithful and just and will forgive us our sins and purify us from all unrighteousness.‚Äù 1 John 1:9 3. We must pray and believe that God will answer us. ‚ÄúTherefore I tell you, whatever you ask for in prayer, believe that you have received it, and it will be yours.‚Äù Mark 11:24 This very day there are so many innocent people that depend on our faith, on our true contrition and on our prayer to silence the power of evil in our world and to end violence and to create peace. If you are reading the news you know that the wars that are occurring have deep roots and change without God‚Äôs intervention is in my humble opinion impossible. We who have faith must call upon God for assistance for God can accomplish what we alone can never hope to do. God is Our Creator, God is Our Father, God is Our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, God is the Holy Spirit that creates Faith, Hope and Love in our world. ‚ÄúBlessed are the peacemakers, for they will be called children of God.‚Äù Matthew 5:9 "The LORD examines the righteous, but the wicked, those who love violence, he hates with a passion." Psalm 11:5 There are little children this very day whose safety and futures depend on our faith, on our true repentance and our prayer for God‚Äôs intervention. Imagine their eyes so full of tears. Imagine their parents desperate for assistance and let us be their lifeline to God! My heart breaks for the people caught in places of violence and war, and I am so grieved especially for the innocent little children and their parents. How do you explain this horror to a little child! How do you make them feel safe! How do you be strong when you feel desperate and without assistance! I invite you to join a Christian Peace Movement called A Peaceful Revolution in the Name of Jesus Christ. Christians all over the world are committing to being peacemakers by believing in the power of One Body of Christ praying together at the Hour of Mercy everyday! The Hour of Mercy is the Time Jesus died for us, 3pm. At this time we come to Jesus with humility, with contrite hearts and with hope that He will help us heal our world of hatred, injustice, violence and war. There will never be peace until God intervenes to make it so because man will always find a way to justify violence. Please imagine in your heart the tears of the little children caught in conflict zones and commit to pray for them everyday. The little ones have done nothing to warrant the horror that surrounds them! A Peaceful Revolution in the Name of Jesus Christ is a Mercy Movement that requires faith, prayer and love for all souls. We pray for God‚Äôs Mercy upon all souls. We pray for an end to hatred, for reconciliation between God and Man and for peace, hope and prosperity where all people can live respectfully with one another without fear and without threat of any form of violence. Be a peacemaker for you are a child of God called to believe in the great power of God‚Äôs love to do what is impossible for man. ‚ÄúJesus looked at them and said, ‚ÄúWith man this is impossible, but not with God; all things are possible with God.‚Äù Mark 10:27

October 15, 2023 (Sunday) ‚ÄúWe came here with four key objectives,‚Äù Secretary of State Antony Blinken told reporters in Egypt: ‚Äúto make clear that the United States stands with Israel; to prevent the conflict from spreading to other places; to work on securing the release of hostages, including American citizens; and to address the humanitarian crisis that exists in Gaza.‚Äù Blinken has been traveling country to country in the Middle East since shortly after the October 7 attack on Israel by Hamas fighters, who crossed into Israel and killed at least 1,300 people, of whom more than 1,000 were civilians, 30 were Americans, 12 were Thais, and 2 were French nationals. They also took 126 hostages, including not only Israelis, apparently, but also 8 Germans, 5 U.S. nationals, and 2 Mexican nationals. Retaliatory strikes by Israeli forces on Gaza since then have killed at least 2,670 people and displaced almost a million. Israel has stopped food, water, fuel, and electricity from getting to Gaza and has told the more than a million residents in northern Gaza to move south to clear the way for a military incursion. Israeli energy minister Israel Katz said the siege would continue until Hamas frees the hostages. About 500 U.S. citizens are in Gaza. The Biden administration has been pushing diplomacy to stop the crisis from spreading. On October 11, Blinken traveled to Israel, where he met with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, and then to Jordan, where he met with the head of the Palestinian Authority that exercises limited government in the West Bank, Mahmoud Abbas. Then he went on to Bahrain, Qatar, United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, and Egypt. Virtually everywhere, he said, he found ‚Äúa shared view that we have to do everything possible to make sure this doesn‚Äôt spread to other places; a shared view to safeguard innocent lives; a shared view to get assistance to Palestinians in Gaza who need it, and we‚Äôre working very much on that.‚Äù Blinken emphasized that the U.S. will stand with Israel ‚Äútoday, tomorrow, and every day‚Ä¶in word and also in deed.‚Äù He noted that the U.S. has moved a second carrier strike group (CSG) to the Eastern Mediterranean. A CSG is a powerful, flexible group of about 7,500 sailors and Marines on a nuclear-powered aircraft carrier, a replenishment ship (which carries oil and supplies), a cruiser, destroyers, and a submarine, as well as various aircraft. The U.S. maintains 11 CSGs. Two of them are now in the Eastern Mediterranean not as provocation, Blinken said, but ‚Äúas a deterrent. It‚Äôs meant to make clear that no one should do anything that could add fuel to the fire in any other place.‚Äù Sending two CSGs to the region is a strong statement, almost certainly designed to address threats by Iran that it will ‚Äúrespond‚Äù if Israel proceeds with a ground invasion of Gaza. Iran backs Hamas‚Äîalthough there is not yet evidence that Iranian officials directly helped plan the October 7 attack‚Äîand also backs Hezbollah, the militant group that controls southern Lebanon. Today, clashes broke out on the border between Israel and Lebanon as Hezbollah fired missiles into Israel and Israeli forces fired artillery back. Israel has ‚Äúthe right‚Äîindeed it has the obligation‚Äîto defend itself against these attacks from Hamas, and to try to do what it can to make sure that this never happens again,‚Äù Blinken said. But, he added, ‚Äú[i]t needs to do it in a way that affirms the shared values that we have for human life and human dignity, taking every possible precaution to avoid harming civilians.‚Äù United Nations Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres implored Hamas to release the hostages immediately and Israel to grant ‚Äúrapid and unimpeded access‚Ä¶for humanitarian supplies and workers for the sake of the civilians in Gaza,‚Äù which ‚Äúis running out of water, electricity and other essential supplies.‚Äù These two issues must not become bargaining chips, he said. ‚Äú[W]e are on the verge of the abyss in the Middle East.‚Äù Opening a gate between Gaza and Egypt would allow supplies to be brought in and would help to move refugees south, away from the northern areas Israel is expected to attack. Relief for Gaza‚Äôs people has been bottled up on the Egyptian side of the border as Israeli officials refuse to guarantee their forces will not bomb relief trucks out of concern they are carrying weapons. The U.S. has put strong pressure on Israel to reopen the water supply to Gaza, especially in the southern region since the influx of refugees was already stressing supplies, and today Israel did so, but observers say that without electricity and fuel, the pumping stations and the plants that take salt out of the water don‚Äôt work. The U.S. is also clearly working to get the U.S. hostages released, but officials will not talk about the details of that operation. Today President Biden appointed Ambassador David Satterfield as the U.S. Special Envoy for Middle East Humanitarian Issues, charging him with bringing ‚Äúurgently needed (truncated)

In the movie "The Last Samurai," the character Ujio plays a significant role, representing loyalty, bravery, and martial prowess within the backdrop of Japan's tumultuous historical period. Ujio's character embodies the essence of a samurai, showcasing utmost dedication to his leader, Katsumoto Moritsu, and a readiness to do whatever it takes to protect Katsumoto and the values of the samurai. Ujio's character is not just about unwavering loyalty; he is also a remarkable swordsman and considered one of the finest warriors among Katsumoto's samurai. His combat skills are showcased in various intense battle scenes throughout the film. Ujio exhibits his martial talent and courage in these moments of action, revealing his role as a fierce protector of his people and their traditions. However, Ujio's character also experiences personal growth and inner conflict. At the outset, he adheres strictly to traditional samurai values and is deeply committed to preserving their way of life. Nevertheless, as the film progresses, Ujio confronts the internal struggle of balancing tradition with adapting to the changing society of Japan during the 19th century. One of the pivotal moments of the film is the clash between Ujio and the main character, Nathan Algren. This duel encapsulates the complexity of their characters and their approach to the situation. Ujio enters the duel with unwavering determination and courage, defending his honor and the honor of the samurai. Behind his confidence, however, lies the pressure of his role within Katsumoto's samurai and a desire to uphold their collective reputation. Nathan Algren, on the other hand, is not a traditional samurai but a former American soldier who has learned much about the art of swordsmanship and the samurai spirit from Katsumoto and his companions. In this duel, he doesn't fight merely for himself but to demonstrate respect and gratitude for the teachings of Katsumoto and the samurai. It's a challenge within himself to see if he can stand his ground against a formidable warrior like Ujio. This clash symbolizes the clash of cultures and complex emotions within the characters. At the start, their limited understanding of each other's culture and language leads to misunderstandings and conflicts. However, as they spend more time together, both Ujio and Algren learn and gain respect for one another. This interaction highlights a central theme of the movie: the potential for understanding and respect between different cultures, set against the backdrop of Japan's confrontation with tradition and modernization in the 19th century. In conclusion, Ujio's character in "The Last Samurai" represents more than just a loyal samurai; he embodies the spirit of the samurai, their unwavering dedication, and their martial prowess. His character arc, especially in the duel with Nathan Algren, illustrates the internal conflicts and personal growth experienced by both characters. Through this clash and their evolving relationship, the film conveys a message of potential understanding and respect between diverse cultures during a transformative period in Japan's history. Nestled in the heart of the picturesque Aveyron region of southern France, the Chateau de Najac stands as a timeless testament to the grandeur of the medieval era. This magnificent fortress, perched atop a rugged hill, overlooks the enchanting village of Najac with an air of regal authority, casting a mesmerizing spell over all who lay eyes upon it. Constructed in the 13th century during the tumultuous times of the Albigensian Crusade, the Chateau de Najac was not just a symbol of power but a guardian of a region rife with conflict. Its formidable stone walls, constructed to withstand sieges, rise majestically from the rocky terrain, each stone echoing centuries of history and power. As you approach the chateau, the very journey to its gates is an adventure through time, as you tread the very path that knights and noble ladies once walked, perhaps en route to or returning from the Crusade. Within the chateau's walls, the ambiance is nothing short of awe-inspiring. A tranquil courtyard, surrounded by well-preserved battlements, transports you back to the days when chivalry reigned supreme. The whispers of the wind and the echoing footsteps serve as a haunting reminder of all who have passed through these hallowed halls. Stepping into the chateau's interiors, you are enveloped by a sense of mystery and antiquity. Stone archways lead you into dimly lit chambers where the tapestries tell stories of valor and love, offering a glimpse into the courtly life of the Middle Ages. The great hall, with its vaulted ceilings and colossal hearth, exudes an aura of grandeur that only the noblest of feasts and gatherings could have filled. But it is from the highest tower of the Chateau de Najac that you are truly transported to another world. Ascend the winding staircase to be greeted by a panoramic vista that sweeps across the Aveyron landscape, just as it did when this fortress was both a stronghold and a refuge during its tumultuous history. In every corner of the Chateau de Najac, you can almost hear the echoes of battles won and lost, and the whispers of lovers who once sought refuge in its walls. This medieval masterpiece is more than a monument; it is a living, breathing testament to human history, offering a profound connection to the past that is both emotive and stirring. A visit to the Chateau de Najac is a journey through time, an encounter with the spirits of chivalry, and an opportunity to lose oneself in the enchanting story of France's medieval heritage.

Today, President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi met with French Minister of Foreign Affairs, Catherine Colonna. The meeting was also attended by Minister of Foreign Affairs, Sameh Shourky. Spokesman for the Presidency, Counselor Ahmed Fahmy, said both sides affirmed the importance of the strategic nature of the distinguished relations between the two countries across the economic, development and cultural fields, in addition to intensive coordination and consultation between the two sides, regarding various political and security files of common interest. This was reflected during the past days in terms of extensive calls between President El-Sisi and French President Emmanuel Macron, with the aim of supporting and safeguarding security and stability in the Middle East, the Mediterranean Basin and Africa. Views were exchanged on the latest regional developments, especially the military escalation in the Gaza Strip. The French minister of foreign affairs presented France‚Äôs view in this regard, while praising Egypt‚Äôs key role in dealing with this vital regional issue, with wisdom and responsibility, from various political and humanitarian aspects. Views were aligned on the gravity of the current situation and its threat to the region‚Äôs security and stability, as well as the need to prevent the expansion of the conflict, to protect civilians and prevent targeting them and to respect international humanitarian law. President El-Sisi highlighted the deteriorating humanitarian conditions in the Gaza Strip and the need for the international community to assume its responsibilities by providing an urgent humanitarian and relief aid to the people of the Strip and alleviating their suffering. The President stressed the need for de-escalation, as well as the rejection to expose civilians to policies of collective punishment, such as siege, starvation or displacement. The two sides also agreed on the importance of diligent international work towards settling the Palestinian issue by reaching a just and comprehensive solution, based on the two-state solution in accordance with the terms of reference of international legitimacy, so as to realize security and stability for all the peoples of the region.

Today, President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi received a phone call from President of the Russian Federation, Vladimir Putin. The two Presidents discussed developments in the regional situation and the latest in the escalation in the Gaza Strip. President El-Sisi and President Putin reviewed diplomatic efforts underway to contain the situation and prevent the expansion of the violence and conflict, which jeopardizes security and stability in the region. The two Presidents agreed on the importance of giving priority to the path of promoting calm and restoring security and stability. They reiterated the need to prioritize the protection of civilians and the prevention of targeting them, noting the gravity of the humanitarian conditions in the Gaza Strip. President El-Sisi and President Putin also underscored the urgency to provide safe access to the humanitarian relief and assistance. The were also aligned with regard to the importance of working, in earnest, toward addressing the causes of the crisis, particularly the continued absence of political prospects to settle the Palestinian cause in a just and lasting manner and to establish a Palestinian State in accordance with the terms of reference of international legitimacy that were agreed-upon.

Today, President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi received a phone call from President of the United States of America, Joe Biden. The call came within the framework of following-up on the outcome of the last visit to Cairo by U.S. Secretary of State, Antony Blinken, and as part of the ongoing consultations between the two countries on the latest developments in the tense regional situation and the military escalation in the Gaza Strip. Spokesman for the Presidency, Counselor Ahmad Fahmy, said the two Presidents concurred about the gravity of the current situation and the necessity to contain it in a way that would not allow the expansion of the cycle of the conflict and threatening regional security and stability. President El-Sisi and American President Biden also agreed on the priority of protecting civilians and delivering humanitarian aid to the Gaza Strip. They also discussed the ongoing consultations in this regard with the United Nations, as well as efforts exerted to advance and revive the peace track. President El-Sisi and President Biden agreed to continue consultations and coordination of efforts in the coming period.

Geronimo was an Apache leader and medicine man best known for his fearlessness in resisting anyone‚ÄìMexican or American‚Äîwho attempted to remove his people from their tribal lands. He repeatedly evaded capture and life on a reservation, and during his final escape, a full quarter of the U.S. standing army pursued him and his followers. Here are some interesting facts about Geronimo that you may not know: 1. The origins of his name are disputed. The man who would become the most feared Indian leader of the 19th century was born sometime in the 1820s into the Bedonkohe, the smallest band of the Chiricahua Apache tribe that inhabited what is now New Mexico and Arizona. His given name was Goyahkla (‚ÄúThe One Who Yawns‚Äù), but as a young man he earned the moniker ‚ÄúGeronimo‚Äù after distinguishing himself in Apache raids against the Mexicans. The source of the name remains the subject of debate. Some historians believed it arose from frightened Mexican soldiers invoking the Catholic St. Jerome when facing the warrior in battle, while others argue that it was simply a Mexican nickname or a mispronunciation of ‚ÄúGoyahkla.‚Äù 2. Geronimo‚Äôs wife and children were murdered when he was a young man. Geronimo came of age during a period of bitter conflict between the Chiricahua Apaches and the Mexicans. In response to the Apaches‚Äô penchant for staging raids to gather horses and provisions, the Mexican government had begun ambushing Apache settlements and offering lucrative bounties for their scalps. In 1851, while Geronimo and several other warriors were in the town of Janos on a trading mission, Colonel Jose Maria Carrasco and a detachment of around 400 Mexican soldiers ransacked his Bedonkohe encampment and slaughtered many of its inhabitants. When Geronimo returned later that night, he found that his mother, his wife and his three young children had all been murdered. 3. He broke out of U.S. Indian reservations on three different occasions. In the 1840s and 1850s, the Mexican-American War and the Gadsden Purchase placed the Chiricahua Apaches‚Äô domain within the boundaries of the expanding United States. Geronimo and the Apaches violently resisted the influx of white settlers, but following several years of war with the U.S. Army, they reluctantly negotiated a peace. By 1876, most of the Chiricahuas had been shipped to San Carlos, an arid and inhospitable reservation located in Arizona. Geronimo avoided the reservation until 1877, when he was captured by Indian agents and brought to San Carlos in chains. 4. He was an accomplished artist who sold paintings to tourists late in life. 5. He was also an accomplished horseman who could ride standing up on two horses at once. 6. He died at Fort Sill, Oklahoma on February 17th, 1909.

President Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan spoke by phone with Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis of Greece.

Views were exchanged regarding the conflict between Israel and Palestine and numerous concerning developments, particularly the human rights violations in the region.

President Erdoƒüan stated that T√ºrkiye has been exerting all kinds of efforts for this conflict, which may lead to utterly negative consequences regionally and globally, to end, and will continue to do so.

Noting that regional countries should endeavor to end the conflict and human rights violations as well as protecting the peace, and that they should give messages to the world to that effect, President Erdoƒüan said that it would be right to take steps that would reduce reaction rather than increase them as soon as possible.

President Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan spoke by phone with Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of the United Kingdom.

The call addressed the current situation in the Israel-Palestine conflict, policies that should be followed in order to restore peace in the region and urgent measures for the resolution of the severe humanitarian crises.

Noting that the international community, the Western countries in particular, should effectively object to the human rights violations in Gaza, President Erdoƒüan stated that it is important to remember and deliver the unfulfilled promises made to Palestine over the years instead of taking provocative steps that deepen the crisis.

I am being attacked by another page and need to get on top of this before it gets out of hand. I hate drama and conflict so I really hope this puts out the fire and doesn't add to it, but I don't know what else to do. The derogatory and frankly dangerous things being Said about me are simply not true. I haven't been in contact with this person for over a year after blocking Their page because of being attacked by them in the past over RTN, the private Assessment company I partnered with after my Son was diagnosed by them. For some unknown reason this advocate has suddenly started attacking me again and Their friends are supporting them despite me being completely oblivious to what I have supposedly done. They are saying I've been bulling them, accused me of being transphobic (anyone who knows me, knows that's utterly not true) and dead naming, which if I did do, it was because I was unaware of any name change (name changes is Something I'm very supportive of which is why I changed my name) I have had problems with a few Autistic advocates in the past and have gone on the defensive and also blocked them. I know people say stuff about me behind my back, but there isn't much I can do about it, other than get on with my life and continue to be me. I'm also being lambasted for saying the words regressive advocates, which I didn't actually know the meaning of. I thought it meant angry for not agreeing. But this is not the case and for that I apologise profusely to anyone offended. I know I have a lot of support, but I have seen people crash and burn because of unfounded and hurtful accusations spreading and destroying lives. I don't deserve this, I was only ever trying to help Autistic people through my posts, my talks, my books and even my photography. So here is my message to this person üíï I'm very sorry we fell out. I was trying to protect my mental health and I took what you were saying last year as a personal attack on me and my integrity. I'm sorry if I dead named you, this was absolutely not deliberate and I honestly didn't realise it had happened. Please stop this, I honestly have no issues with you and even love your honesty and art. I miss when we were friends but I was really hurt which is why I blocked you. I watched the tick tock video threatening death (to I assume me) which has scared me beyond all reason. I have a family, I cannot understand why this was something anyone would think was OK to do. This situation has also hurt my wife and kids, who as you know are also Autistic and their anxiety is making them ill. Please, please, leave me alone, I haven't done anything to you and if some advocates are angry at me for things I've said, then I'm afraid I cannot please everyone, I can only do my best and block or delete anyone who sets off my RSD, trauma and depression. I respect anyone who tries to advocate for our community, but I that doesn't mean we have to agree about everything and when people say hurtful things or break down my posts looking for ways to pick at me, this sets off my rsd and I get defensive. I wish you all the happiness in the world despite whats happening, and I hope one day perhaps we can communicate in a friendly manner again. *To my supporters. Please know that I am not ok, I am very sick now and may take some time away from the Advocate side of this page, not definitely, but very possibly. I will continue to share my photography as it is the only thing that is keeping me from going down a deep hole of despair.

We must win this war of souls. In its war against Hamas, Israel has a duty to defend its territory and its citizens, but it must also defend its humanity. Our war is with Hamas, not with the Palestinian people. Palestinian civilians deserve to enjoy peace and prosperity in their homeland, and even in the midst of conflict their basic human rights should be recognized by all sides. This refers not only to Israel, but also to Egypt, which shares a border with the Gaza Strip, and which has partially sealed that border. Right now, the minds of both Israelis and Palestinians are filled to the brim with their own pain, and no space is left to even acknowledge the pain of the other side. But outsiders who are not themselves immersed in pain should make an effort to empathize with all suffering humans, rather than lazily seeing only part of the terrible reality. It is the job of outsiders to help maintain a space for peace. Read the full article on TIME: bit.ly/YNH-TIME-Oct23:=:https://time.com/6324254/israel-hamas-war-peace-yuval-noah-harari/

The JCRC is horrified by the senseless, hate-driven murder of Wadea Al-Fayoume, an innocent Palestinian-American boy, yesterday in Illinois. We condemn any and all attacks on innocent Muslims or Arabs, including several local incidents we are aware of. Hamas‚Äô barbaric attack on Israel, and the searing grief, anger, and fear it has triggered, cannot excuse vengeful, violent lashing out that is itself inhumane and rooted in hatred. There is no explanation for brutally stabbing a six-year-old boy once, let alone 26 times. We extend our deepest condolences to Wadea‚Äôs parents and family, and wish his mother, who was seriously injured in this attack, a speedy recovery. May Wadea‚Äôs memory be a blessing.

This skull, wearing medieval chainmail, was discovered in a mass grave on the Island of Gotland, Sweden. It is believed to be connected to the Battle of Visby, which took place in 1361. This violent medieval battle occurred between the inhabitants of Gotland and the Danes, with the Danes ultimately emerging as the victors. The presence of such remains offers a glimpse into the historical conflict and the use of protective armor during this period.

"But I will send a fire upon the wall of GAZA, Which shall devour its palaces. "I will cut off the inhabitant from Ashdod, And the one who holds the scepter from Ashkelon; I will turn My hand against Ekron, And the remnant of the Philistines shall perish,‚Äù Says the Lord God. Scripture can be so eeriely accurate as to raise hairs on one's head! Selah ü§î PS: And then someone says ati, it was written by men who sat down and elaborately invented all the stories and tales! A simple audit of the number of prophecies in that book that have come to pass alone numbers in the hundreds! How could someone writing from over 2,400 years ago be so accurate? How can some small group get so many events right, down to days and names? Let's be real! üßê PPS: I have been forced to add this. My sharing of the scripture above does not in any way that I... a) support the brutalization of any civilians on both sides of this conflict, such as witnessed by the horrible events that precipitated this retaliation, or the countless past events against the Palestinians by the Israeli IDF b) justify any "genocide" or "extermination" of any people, terms that have been thrown around in this conflict c) trivialize the great suffering that the Palestinian people have had to endure for decades under this occupation. d) justify the continued oppression of the Palestinians in that place. ü•∫

Many in the mainstream media are already painting the narrative that any retaliation from Israel will be unwarranted and calls for ‚Äòpeace‚Äô will be on Israel‚Äôs shoulders. And if you don‚Äôt know the history of the Israeli/Palestinian conflict, you‚Äôre likely to believe that narrative. But history and context are important to understand. Calls for peace have been attempted for multiple times over the past few decades. Israel has made MULTIPLE concessions in an attempt to bring this conflict to an end. Every single time, however, those deals have been rejected by the Palestinian government. Why? Because there is no deal that can be made that Palestine or any other terroristic anti-Semitic group will agree with, other than the absolute destruction of the Jewish people. Israel has offered a two-state solution. It was turned down. This conflict is about killing all of the Jews, period.

There is some deep perversion in Britain whenever Israel is involved in a conflict And it is the word you just used - proportion. I've heard it in the last few days excessively. Proportionality in conflict rarely exists, but if we were to decide that we should have this fetish about proportionality then that would mean that in retaliation for what Hamas did in Israel on Saturday Israel should try to locate a music festival in Gaza for instance, and good luck with that, should try to find a music festival in Gaza and rape precisely the number of women that Hamas raped on Saturday, kill precisely the number of young people that Hamas killed on Saturday. üó£Ô∏è Hey everyone, let‚Äôs talk about why checking in with your partner is so important for building a healthy, long-lasting relationship. It‚Äôs easy to get caught up in our busy lives, but taking the time to check in can make all the difference. Here‚Äôs why it matters...‚úçüèæ ü§ù Open Communication: When we check in with our partner, we create a safe space for open and honest communication. It‚Äôs a chance to share our thoughts, feelings, and any concerns we may have. By actively listening and expressing ourselves, we deepen our understanding of each other and strengthen our bond. ‚ù§Ô∏è Emotional Support: Life can be tough, and checking in allows us to offer much-needed emotional support to our partner. It shows them that we‚Äôre there for them, ready to listen and provide comfort when they need it most. This kind of support nurtures the foundation of our relationship and helps us navigate through life‚Äôs challenges together. üîó Strengthening Bonds: Regular check-ins are an opportunity to nurture the bond we share with our partner. It‚Äôs a chance to appreciate each other, express gratitude, and celebrate the small moments that make our relationship special. By investing time and effort into our connection, we create a strong sense of security, trust, and intimacy. üíî Conflict Resolution: Let‚Äôs face it, conflicts happen in every relationship. Checking in allows us to address issues promptly and constructively. It‚Äôs a chance to talk openly about concerns, find common ground, and work towards resolution with love and respect. By tackling conflicts head-on, we build a stronger and healthier relationship. üå± Growing Together: People change and grow over time, and relationships should too. Regular check-ins provide an opportunity for personal and mutual growth. By sharing our dreams, aspirations, and individual goals, we support each other‚Äôs personal development while strengthening our connection as a couple.

Hi everyone. I thought I‚Äôd compile together as much as I could on Glorfindel, as one of the mightiest of Elves, and unique in that not only had he returned to Middle Earth from Valinor, he was also active in all the Three Ages of Middle Earth and possibly well into the Fourth Age too. Glorfindel also known as Laurefindel√´ in the Quenya tongue meaning ‚ÄúGolden haired‚Äù was one of the mightiest and valiant of all the Elves. He was born sometime during the Years of the Trees in Valinor and there is nothing known of his parentage except that he had kinship with Turgon. It is this and his allegiance to Turgon that compelled him to cross the Helcarax√´ to exile in Middle Earth, even though in his heart he was against leaving Aman and so took no part in the Kinslaying. Once entering Middle Earth he like other followers of Turgon settled in Vinyamar in Nevrast in West Beleriand just on the slopes of Mount Taras. While conflict continued with Morgoth‚Äôs armies it was after the Dagor Aglareb, the third battle of Beleriand in F.A. 60 that Turgon‚Äôs thoughts were drawn back to Tumladen Vale where Ulmo had guided him a decade earlier, and it was here in this very place that he built the Hidden City of Gondolin reaching completion in the year 116 of the First Age. Glorfindel who had always been loyal to Turgon was awarded chief of the House of the Golden Flower, one of the great noble houses of Gondolin, whose shields bore a rayed sun. His raiment was embroidered with Golden threads, decorated with Celandine and he became beloved by all the Gondolindrim. Having not participated in the previous battles, Gondolin within the hidden valley remained safe. However in F.A. 472 Glorfindel followed Turgon into battle at the plain of Anfauglith and upon the Fen of Serech to fight at the terrible and devastating Nirnaeth Arnoediad, where upon the battlefield waiting for their chance to act they finally broke through the lines of Orcs and met with the guard of Fingon, just before Morgoth was to unleash the full might of Angband upon them, including that of Glaurung. During the fight Glaurung became sorely wounded by Azagh√¢l the leader of the Dwarves of Belegost but was slain in the process forcing their army to leave the battlefield. This did not help Fingon and Turgon on the Western side so the battle went sour and the alliance was failing. Turgon‚Äôs and Fingon‚Äôs forces thus retreated to the Pass of Sirion with Glorfindel and Ecthelion both at the rear but they were set upon by Gothmog who fought Fingon in single combat. However another Balrog came and bound Fingon with his whip so he couldn‚Äôt move and so Fingon, elder brother of Turgon died by Gothmog‚Äôs black axe. Turgon and his host were now in trouble but if not for H√∫rin‚Äôs bravery and sacrifice this day enabling Turgon and his followers to flee back to Gondolin which still remained hidden from Morgoth, all would have been lost. Not much is written here of Glorfindel in this battle but I‚Äôm sure his sword and dirk counted towards many Orc deaths this day. For 38 years Gondolin remained safe but inner turmoils and dark deeds where upon Maeglin, having been captured by Morgoth, tortured and promised to have both the city and Idril who he secretly loved, gave away the city‚Äôs secret location. So it was in the year 510 Morgoth attacked Gondolin. Glorfindel was ordered to defend the Great Market area on the Eastern side of the city from advancing Orcs. His plan was to flank this invading army but he and his guard became ambushed. Surrounded by Orcs led by Balrogs they fought for hours until a fire-drake came at them and they had no choice but to retreat with the few survivors they had left. This dragon levelled this entire area with flame burning everything, all of its stores and wears. Turgon sent forth his Host of the Harp to help them but instead their leader Salgant in his cowardice led his men to the Lesser Market where he lived. There his soldiers started to fret and feared for Glorfindel‚Äôs safety, so they abandoned their leader. They arrived to aid Glorfindel in time but many of them perished within the fires that engulfed this area. Arriving at the city‚Äôs centre, The Square of the Palace, where great fountains had been built here to add to the beauty of this part of the city, they took refuge. Ecthelion who was Warden of the Great Gate was wounded and Galdor, Lord of the Folk of the Tree, was still engaged in battle which had enabled Tuor to bring Ecthelion here and Egalmoth, Lord of the Heavenly Arch had still to arrive. Glorfindel thus joined Tuor in defending the Square. They fought valiantly but could not prevent the Dragon that came upon them, breaking through their line of defence followed by Orcs and Balrogs including among this dark host, Gothmog. Ecthelion although wounded fought this threat so the others may find time to escape and in so doing killed Gothmog, Lord of Balrogs, but in the process he too was slain. Turgon ordered those that survived to follow Tuor (truncated)

The scapegoat plays a crucial role in the intricate dynamics of narcissistic relationships. As the one with the potential to expose the narcissist's manipulation, deception, and lies, the scapegoat inevitably becomes the outcast of the social setting. This phenomenon occurs as a defensive mechanism the narcissist employs, aiming to protect their egotistical facade and maintain control over those around them. By designating the scapegoat as the outcast, the narcissist effectively deflects attention away from their own behaviour, redirecting it onto an innocent party. This ultimately allows them to continue with their exploitative tactics unchecked. The scapegoat, on the other hand, becomes burdened with the weight of the narcissist's transgressions, suffering the consequences of being excluded from social circles. The narcissist's manipulation, deception, and lies often manifest as a web of untruths expertly woven together. The scapegoat, however, possesses an innate ability to see through this veil of deception. Their astute observation skills and keen intuition grant them the insight required to pinpoint the narcissist's true nature. This insight threatens the narcissist's carefully constructed persona, making the scapegoat a dangerous individual who could dismantle their entire fa√ßade. In order to maintain their position of power and influence, the narcissist skillfully manipulates others into believing that the scapegoat is the instigator of conflict. By painting the scapegoat as untrustworthy, emotionally unstable, or even mentally ill, the narcissist successfully tarnishes their reputation and credibility. This ensures that any information or accusations brought forth by the scapegoat are swiftly dismissed or deemed invalid. In conclusion, the scapegoat's potential to expose the narcissist's manipulation, deception, and lies makes them a threat to the narcissist's carefully constructed image. As a result, the scapegoat is often shunned and labelled as the outcast, serving as a stark reminder of the narcissist's insidious tactics. This unfortunate circumstance perpetuates the narcissist's hold over their victims and enables them to continue their manipulative behaviour unchecked. Vanavond net na zeven uur heeft een gewapende schietpartij plaatsgevonden gericht op drie personen op de kruising van de Saincteclette en de 9de Linielaan, in het centrum van Brussel. Twee personen zijn daarbij overleden. Een derde, een taxichauffeur zou buiten levensgevaar zijn. De federale noodfase is afgekondigd deze avond om 21.13. Deze federale fase impliceert de mobilisatie van het nationaal crisiscentrum en van de nationale crisiscellen. Op dat moment is het dossier gefederaliseerd. De overname door het federaal parket kwam er omwille van het mogelijke terroristisch motief van de schietpartij. In de loop van de avond is er een opeising geweest op sociale media. Die boodschap was opgenomen door een persoon die zich identificeert als de aanslagpleger. Hij zegt zich te inspireren op de Islamitische Staat. Tijdens dezelfde boodschap werd de Zweedse nationaliteit van de slachtoffers aangehaald als mogelijk motief voor de daad. Op dit moment is er geen enkele aanwijzing dat de aanslag gelinkt zou zijn aan het Isra√´lisch-Palestijns conflict. Op basis van deze feiten en van de opeising zijn dringende veiligheidsmaatregelen genomen om de Zweedse supporters zo goed mogelijk te beschermen. GOVERNOR INUWA YAHAYA VISITS NSCDC BOSS, HARPS ON COMPREHENSIVE REVIEW OF OPERATIONAL STRATEGIES TO COMBAT CRIMES As part of strategies to control farmers/ herders clashes and improved security in schools as well as ensure general security of lives and property in Gombe State, the State Governor, Alhaji Muhammadu Inuwa Yahaya, CON, has demanded for the deployment of more personnel of the Nigeria Security and Civil Defence Corps (NSCDC) to the state, specifically those in Agro Rangers Unit and general duty operatives to assist in the control of farmers/clashes among other forms of insecurity bedeviling the state. Governor Inuwa stated this while addressing the NSCDC Commandant General, Dr Ahmed Abubakar Audi, mni ofr, and other top members of the management team at the Corps' National Headquarters in Abuja. According to him, Gombe shares boarder with five states most of whom have suffered crises, thus, making his state to become relatively populated with incidences of clashes between farmers and herders especially when there is massive migration by the latter. The Governor expressed hope that the presence of Agro Rangers personnel who are specifically trained to attend to such complex issues of farmers and herders conflict will save the state from such menace towards the end of October as the rains cease. In his words, the demand for additional deployment of Agro Rangers personnel before October ends is to avert incidences of clashes as movement of cattle rearers usually commence at that period and the personnel will be of immense benefits to control clashes and mediate conflict if any. Further on the deployment, he expressed optimism that if security of lives and property was achieved, it will result in food security. The Governor decried high rate of out of school children especially girl child which he attributed to closure of almost all boarding schools for girls in the state except one, and further solicited the assistance of the Corps to reverse the situation by ensuring safe and secured environment for learning, describing the NSCDC as a serious stakeholder in security. He also promised as Chairman of Northern Governors' Forum to create opportunity for the Commandant General to address them on security issues whenever the Governors will convene a meeting. Responding, the CG assured Governor Inuwa of his agency's cooperation and collaboration, stating that his request will be attended on the completion of the ongoing quarterly training of Agro Rangers personnel. He explained that Agro Rangers Unit has resolved more than 1000 cases nationwide, adding that as a special unit, Agro Rangers provide security for farmers and agro allied investments. On the protection of schools, Dr Audi explained that as a lead agency in the protection of critical national assets and Infrastructure his administration will respond to the protection of schools in Gombe State under the safe Schools Project whose Headquarters is housed by the Corps. NSCDC promotes and adopt non-kinetic strategy which generates more results, the Commandant General added. CSC Babawale Zaid Afolabi National Public Relations Officer NSCDC NHQ, Abuja Gombe State Government Ismaila Uba Misilli Muhammadu Inuwa Yahaya

text: I AM NOT A VET! This on my bio so that I‚Äôm not misrepresenting myself, that was not ever my intention. I hate giving air time to negativity but I am now forced to address the issue after a vet made some very unprofessional comments with 50 percent of the information that was readily available. I also had a complaint made recently to MPI via the veterinary association at the behest of a canterbury vet I‚Äôm aware of. I regularly recommend veterinary treatment/assessment to clients who ask me to see their horses. I recently saw a horse in Invercargill, the owner was distraught with worry and I said this horse presents with indications(palpation and intermittent right side hind lameness)of ulcers‚Ä¶..days later the horse was scoped and had serious ulcers. This is not a competition. The things I talk about on my page is encouraging people to seek vet help. I appreciate my vets and I show mine gratitude when ever I can! They have contributed to saving the lives of my horses many times. I I also appreciate their limitations and that they don‚Äôt have crystal balls. When I started doing this work 4 years ago I never thought this page would grow the way it has. Perhaps I haven‚Äôt been proactive enough about what my qualifications are, they are not formal and I am always learning. That being said, I will not minimise how much of my life I have invested into horses and being a good alround horse person, I talk the talk and I walk the walk. I can cold shoe a horse, I trim my own, I can start horses, I have rehabbed many horses, I read allot of equine books, I have had several equine businesses, I ride to a high standard and I bred damn nice horses. I live in a tiny home my partner and I built to afford the horses I own and to lead a sustainable lifestyle in keeping with the planet , many sacrifices have been made along the way. I am a mother to three wonderful boys (14 year old twin boys and a 9 year old) I have built everything I have from nothing and with a smile on my face. I know resilience. I am now just over my 40th dissection, some of the things I‚Äôve seen I could have never imagined or had seen any public information about. Some days, I wish I didn‚Äôt know‚Ä¶.gignorance is bliss! But I think dissection works is the pinnacle of understanding how horses function and how our intervention can be so damaging. I was accused today by a vet that I think I‚Äôm a guru, I do not and anyone who knows me personally knows I am very aware of my limitations. But I have worked with ALLOT of dysfunctional horses and now looked inside 40, that is not to be diminished. It is slave labour for little return. Learning is a journey. All I am trying to do is help people see anatomy as interesting and relatable to their own horses. If I state something as pathology in a horse it‚Äôs because I‚Äôve had a vet look over the information. I stepped away from the successful charity I started 5 years ago retraining horses because of politics, it appears it‚Äôs been out of the pot and into the fire. Being a part of an animal welfare charity means I have made good connections with the right authorities and have a very good grasp on animal welfare. I know the rules, I abide by them. So much has happened in the background I have shouldered and kept my head up but today was too much. In New Zealand we have a real problem with tall poppy syndrome and it‚Äôs bullshit! The worst thing is seeing women cut women down! Children/families are dying in conflict at the moment, get some perspective!

The very serious conflict in Israel and Gaza, has also spilled out into the streets of the West as an ideological battle for support, with many communities asking for fellow citizens to take sides as a show of solidarity. In my opinion, as Australians, our loyalty should always be to our country first. We should not betray the benefits of the peace we enjoy as Australians to forgo our values and national interest to side with views and ideas that are not welcomed in our country. Although it can be complex living in a diverse, multi cultural/faith nation during times of conflict, we already have a set of moral and ethical principles to guide us when navigating such challenges. Even though our country may at times fall short of its aspirations, there is no denying that many people who have sought refuge from war and atrocity find themselves living in countries like Australia. There is a reason for that, and it should be appreciated and respected at times like this.

SAYING GOODBYE TO CHRISSY üò• SUZANNE SOMERS, the actress and fitness entrepreneur best known for her comedic role as Chrissy Snow on the 1970s sitcom Three's Company, has died at the age of 76. Somers passed away peacefully at her home in Palm Springs, California on October 15, her publicist confirmed. She had been battling breast cancer for over two decades, having been first diagnosed in her 50s after previously overcoming skin cancer in her 30s. "She survived an aggressive form of breast cancer for over 23 years," said publicist R Couri Hay. "Her family was gathered to celebrate her 77th birthday on October 16. Instead, they will celebrate her extraordinary life." Somers skyrocketed to fame as bubbly blonde Chrissy on Three's Company, appearing in over 100 episodes from 1977 to 1981 alongside co-stars John Ritter and Joyce DeWitt. With her portrayal of the stereotypical "dumb blonde," she became one of the most recognizable faces on 1970s television. However, Somers was fired from the show after demanding a substantial pay raise. "I was making $30,000 an episode, and I just wanted them to pay me what all the guys were making on TV," she told ET in 2021 of the conflict. "But the show said no, so I went on strike." Prior to Three's Company, Somers had a memorable if brief role in the 1973 film American Graffiti. She later starred as Carol Foster Lambert on the 1990s sitcom Step by Step. Additional TV credits included hosting Candid Camera and her own talk show. Somers also competed on Dancing with the Stars in 2015. Off screen, the actress built a successful business empire around health and beauty products. She promoted the ThighMaster exercise device in ubiquitous infomercials and launched her own line of supplements, skin care items, and hormone replacement therapies. Somers also authored several self-help and diet books. Despite criticism from some in the medical community for advocating alternative cancer treatments, Somers said she controlled her illness through natural methods. "I'm very selective about my conventional medicine," she declared. In July 2022, Somers revealed via Instagram that her breast cancer had returned after a long remission. "I'm a fighter and I'll continue to fight it with every tool God has given me," she wrote at the time. "It's only one tiny aspect of my life." Alan Hamel, Somers' husband of 46 years, said she passed peacefully at home surrounded by family. A small private burial will be held, followed by a memorial service in November. Fans and colleagues praised Somers' sunny persona and resilience. Co-star Joyce DeWitt called her "a gift of life to everyone who knew her." Marie Osmond said she left "a legacy of love." Somers is fondly remembered for her vivacious, comedic talent and trailblazing business success. But her courage battling cancer, willingness to speak openly of her diagnosis, and commitment to aging with vitality may form the most inspiring part of her legacy. She once said, "Aging is much more about what you have inside than your wrinkles."

At least 30% of conflict between partners comes from misunderstandings. We think we‚Äôre getting a message we‚Äôre not getting (often it‚Äôs ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt care about you‚Äù) which can be more related to past experiences than it is the reality of the moment, and then we react to what we‚Äôve created in our mind, leaving our partner feeling misunderstood and triggered. Your reasons for misunderstanding makes sense. Misunderstandings aren‚Äôt random. They‚Äôre related to real events from the past (childhood, former relationships, or events in you current relationship) that have given you good reason to jump to conclusions. Our brains are wired to jump to conclusions for the sake of efficiency and staying safe. At the same time, partners who are trying to do better and grow can get boxed in by misunderstandings, and everyone feels demoralized and stuck. What‚Äôs the solution? Curiosity. Before reacting, try to step back and say ‚Äúhey, I think we might be missing each other. The next ECO hunter to tag out was Phillip Foor from Everett Pa in zone9. We talked with Phil on Saturday evening of the drawing and he booked in immediately‚Ä¶but there was a rub. The week before his elk hunt here Phil was going to be moose hunting in New Foundland and his scheduled return home was going to conflict with the start of his elk hunt. Phil wasn‚Äôt to be back home here in PA until Monday morning some time so he was going to miss at least the first two days barring any type of travel delays. Unfortunately Phil wasn‚Äôt able to bring home a moose so he was really hoping to fill his elk tag here. It was Monday late afternoon when Phil and his daughter Riley arrived in camp. He was pretty tired from traveling so Phil, Riley and their guide Kolton George decided to just go for a ride into the zone that evening and hopefully see some elk and give Phil a lay of the land. Kolton had been chomping at the bit for last few days as he had several shooter bulls located on a few of the private properties we have permission on in the zone. As it turned out when they pulled in to one of the properties they saw a shooter bull with cows out in the field‚Ä¶Phil kind of wished he had his gear along at that point. Tuesday dawned with good bugling but heavy fog. They caught a few glimpses of elk throughout the morning but there were no shot opportunities throughout the day and the sunset on the crew that evening pretty quietly. Wednesday morning right off the bat Kolton had Phil In position for a shot at a good bull. At 30 yards Phil drew his bow and took aim. The shot sailed low and forward and Kolton believed it to be a grazing hit across the brisket/leg area. The bull ran off out of the field into the woods and they decided to give him several hours before taking up the trail. They found minimal blood and had to resort to grid searching at which point they actually saw the bull again but weren‚Äôt able to get a shot so they opted to back out. That evening they saw the same bull bugling and chasing cows as if nothing was wrong confirming Koltons thought that it was a grazing superficial hit. The next morning they were back in the same area as the day before trying to locate the bull from the day before but it was a pretty quiet morning. Midday on Thursday Phil got word from back home about an equipment issue at work and he needed to head back to take of it. The hope was for Phil to be able to get it straightened out and then be back up to hunt asap. Friday afternoon Phil was back in camp and along for the adventure now was his son Briar and he was ready to hunt. The trio went for a hike up on the sidehill of the property they had been hunting and it didn‚Äôt take long for them to find elk‚Ä¶one of which being a shooter bull, different than the one from earlier in the week. They were able to sneak within 40yds of the bull but the brush didn‚Äôt allow for a shot and eventually the elk got antsy and moved off ending the day. Saturday morning was pretty slow compared to the days prior so Phil opted to return home again to take care of some more work obligations, but he planned to be back at camp Tuesday afternoon with Briar to finish out the week hunting. Kolton kept an eye out in the zone while Phil was away and began tightening down the game plan. Tuesday afternoon as soon as Briar got off the school bus he hopped in the truck with his dad and headed up to elk camp. When they arrived we talked them into a quick evening hunt and headed to the zone. Kolton had seen a shooter bull earlier in the day, the same one from Friday, and was waiting for Phil and Briar to arrive. This trip Phil had decided to bring his crossbow. They didn‚Äôt have much time left in the day but Koltons plan was to slip down an access road to a food plot that was surrounded by tall grass and use that grass for cover as they approached. They were almost down to the spot where Kolton wanted to slip in to the plot when the bull bugled. Phil and Briar thought the bull sounded like he was in the river but Kolton knew he was in the plot but facing away from them rather causing the bugle so sound further away than what it was. They crept along a lil further to an opening in the grass where they could see in to the field and there he was! It was almost reactionary as Phil shouldered his crossbow and took aim. At 20yards the bolt hit the bull in the boiler room and he charged off across the field. Phil quickly re-cocked and loaded the crossbow and Kolton moved them towards the bull. Phil was able to fire a second bolt in the sweet spot and at hit the bull lunged forward and plowed to the ground and was down‚Ä¶Briars eyes were as big as dinner plates! Congratulations again Phil and thanks for choosing ECO! Also it was great having you and the youngsters in camp and out in the field. It‚Äôs great to see the youth involved and excited about hunting!

üéôÔ∏èCNN LIVE interview on the source of where this conflict is coming from, the experiences we went through on the front lines of combat, and what will happen moving forward. War is what happens when humans fail in finding solutions to problems that always have answers. It often stems from externalizing real and deep rooted emotions, which often cause our outlook to be so clouded that it produces hatred, dehumanization of the other, and zero sum game narratives. Today we are at war, and we have arrived to the consequence of the years of this type of divisive thinking. At some point this war will end, and although we would have all lost lives on both sides, we must honor the lives of those still breathing by making sure we do not repeat this again. A resolution of justice that fulfills the real cultural aspirations of both populations is the only solution. It can only be achieved together, so drop the past and invest everything in the future. Gangtok, October 16 (IPR): Chief Minister Shri Prem Singh Tamang along with Madam Smt Krishna Rai, also the member of Disciplinary Committee of 'Voice' attended the opening day of Sikkim Youth Convention 2023, as the Chief Guest and Guest of Honour at Manan Kendra, today. The two-day Sikkim Youth Convention 2023 organised by Voice NGO and supported by the State Government, with the motto ‚ÄòRevolutionizing Young Minds‚Äô, is being initiated to motivate the Sikkimese youth. Over 900 students from all government and private colleges in Sikkim were invited to attend the Sikkim Youth Convention 2023. Present among others were Ministers Shri K.N. Lepcha, Shri L.N. Sharma, MP Lok Sabha Shri Indra Hang Subba, MLAs Shri Aditya Golay, Shri Sonam Tshering Venchungpa, Shri Y.T. Lepcha and Smt. Farwanti Tamang, Chief Economic Advisor, Dr. Mahendra P. Lama, Political Secretary to CM, Press Secretary to CM, Deputy Mayor GMC, ADGP Law & Order (Sikkim Police), State Government officials, dignitaries, eminent motivational speakers and educationists. The Convention began with the Saraswati Vandana performed by the students of Reeyaz Sangeetalaya followed by offering of Khadas and lighting of the ceremonial lamp by the Chief Guest and other dignitaries. Keynote Speaker, Founder & Director of the Drishti IAS Coaching, Former IAS Officer Dr. Vikas Divyakirti began his address by offering condolences to the bereaved family of the flash flood induced disaster in the State. He shared one of his primary reasons to accept the invitation for the Convention was realising that Sikkim emerges at the top spot with the best workplace conditions for women in the country. He underlined the fundamental parameters of a developed society being categorised under two sub-categories; a) women‚Äôs participation in the State work force and b) society safeguarding the minorities. The Speaker compared his journey to that of the Chief Minister Shri Prem Singh Tamang from clearing the UPSC Civil Services Examination to return to the teaching profession, and expressed that Sikkim is being led by a teacher and that itself is exemplary. Taking one of Dr. Vikas Divyakirti‚Äôs notable contributions, ‚ÄòTriple 8‚Äô formula‚Äîa strategic blueprint he proposes for IAS aspirants, he encouraged the candidates to allocate their day into three vital segments: 8 hours of sleep, 8 hours of focused study, and a crucial 8 hours dedicated to recreation and societal interaction. He discouraged becoming a study robot, engrossed solely in academic materials for countless hours. Instead, he encouraged a holistic approach, where candidates engage with their surroundings, fostering a well-rounded understanding that complements academic prowess. Dr. Divyakirti emphasised that mastering the UPSC examination involves more than mere bookish knowledge. Understanding society, its dynamics, and its challenges is integral to the selection process. This is why he advocates for a balanced approach that not only entails rigorous study but also allows candidates to engage with society, meet friends, and enjoy recreational activities. He also took few questions before closing his interaction for the Convention. Speaker, Senior Professor, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi also Former Member, National Security Advisory Board, Government of India and Sikkim's Chief Economic Advisor, Dr. Mahendra P. Lama in his address, pointed out the fact that there are only a handful of IAS and IPS officers and their numbers should increase. Emphasising on soft powers like Education, the Academician stressed that at Sikkim University, they undertook some of the programmes and researches in the various schools like Global Studies, Peace and Conflict, Sustainable Development, Biotechnology, Climate Change and also Law and Governance. As people play the most important role in shaping the status of the country, education is responsible for shaping a person, he added. He encouraged the students about the importance of Cultivation of education, as it plays a crucial role in technological developments and imparts various skills, values, and awareness. The other distinguished speakers invited for the Convention were Professor, Department of Education, Sikkim University Dr. Yodita Bhutia, who is the first Ph.D and UGC NET holder in Education from Sikkim and Dr. Ashis Sharma, Vice Chancellor, Khangchendzonga State University. The Speakers encouraged a vibrant exchange of ideas, conversations around student research and wider cross-learning, fostering learning, innovation, and meaningful discussions. At the outset, a panel discussion was led by Dr. Satish Rasaily, Shri Tenzing Loden Lepcha, IPS, Dr. Ghanashyam Sharma and Dr. Sumnina Rai. The Organisers thanked the State Government and the Chief Minister also the Patron for the Convention, Shri Prem Singh Tamang for the support extended for the Convention. Hamas & Israel Conflict Mirwaiz Umar Farooq Statement

Last week I posted here reflecting on why the atrocities committed by Hammas on innocent Israeli men, women and children were similar to 9/11, arguing that the terrorists were seeking to provoke Israel into anger as a means of scuppering the relationships that Netanyahu had been building between Isreal and Sunni Arab nations in the region. Today I want to talk about the ways that the Black Saturday attack was not like 9/11. In September 2001, America was targeted by al-Qaeda terrorists as a proxy for western imperialism. The evidence is found in the ‚ÄòLetter to America‚Äô that Osama Bin Laden posted after the event to justify ordering such a horrific attack. That he included ‚Äòenvironmental destruction‚Äô in the list reasons why America deserved to be attacked was a sign that he was desperate to convince people that he was right to order such an atrocity. Hammas felt no need to offer an explanation for why they attacked Israel, and it was not because no words could justify the terrible acts of violence that they committed that day. Israel is not a proxy target to Hammas. It is a state which has been in conflict with the Palestinian people for the past 70 years. Sometimes that war has been one of low level attrition, sometimes it has been all-out combat. The fact that Israel has been forced to become a highly militarised society is a product of this reality. I stress again that this does not mean that the Hammas attacks were justified. Directly targeting civilians, in terror or war, cannot be justified. The point that I am seeking to make is that, horrific though it may be, Black Saturday didn‚Äôt just appear out of a blue sky like the planes that hit the Twin Towers. The world has watched this uneven conflict play out on our tv screens over the past decades. We have witnessed the cycle of terrorism and retribution over and over again. We know what is coming next. The humanity that causes us to weep for the victims of Black Saturday also makes us fear for the people of Gaza. Tonight the London Evening Standard ran a front page story complaining that the level of vocal support for Israel was shamefully sparse given the terrible atrocities that were committed by Hammas. It referenced the disturbing rise in anti-Semitic hate crimes in the past week, rightly condemning them as unacceptable. ‚ÄúAnd yet worse than all this‚Äù the article continued ‚Äúis the sound of silence. Nobody cares it seems.‚Äù I don‚Äôt believe that last statement is true. People do care. They sympathise with those who grieve for the loss of so many in the terror visited on innocent civilians by Hammas on Black Saturday. But they are also aware of the tanks massed on the Gazan border and the air strikes that demolish the homes of Palestinian families. Their silence should not be taken as tacit support for Hammas, nor as a sign of anti-Semitism. People are silent because they are holding their breath in trepidation of what will happen when the most powerful military nation in the Middle East invades one of the most densely populated areas on Earth. If they do not voice support for Israel, it is from fear of being complicit in the killing of innocent civilians.

From 1517 to 1917, what is today Israel, along with much of the Middle East, was ruled by the Ottoman Empire. But World War I dramatically altered the geopolitical landscape in the Middle East. In 1917, at the height of the war, British Foreign Secretary Arthur James Balfour submitted a letter of intent supporting the establishment of a Jewish homeland in Palestine. The British government hoped that the formal declaration‚Äîknown thereafter as the Balfour Declaration‚Äîwould encourage support for the Allies in World War I. When World War I ended in 1918 with an Allied victory, the 400-year Ottoman Empire rule ended, and Great Britain took control over what became known as Palestine (modern-day Israel, Palestine and Jordan). The Balfour Declaration and the British mandate over Palestine were approved by the League of Nations in 1922. Arabs vehemently opposed the Balfour Declaration, concerned that a Jewish homeland would mean the subjugation of Arab Palestinians. The British controlled Palestine until Israel, in the years following the end of World War II, became an independent state in 1947. Conflict Between Jews and Arabs Throughout Israel‚Äôs long history, tensions between Jews and Arab Muslims have existed. The complex hostility between the two groups dates all the way back to ancient times when they both populated the area and deemed it holy. Both Jews and Muslims consider the city of Jerusalem sacred. It contains the Temple Mount, which includes the holy sites al-Aqsa Mosque, the Western Wall, the Dome of the Rock and more. Much of the conflict in recent years has centered around who is occupying the following areas: Gaza Strip: A piece of land located between Egypt and modern-day Israel. Golan Heights: A rocky plateau between Syria and modern-day Israel. West Bank: A territory that divides part of modern-day Israel and Jordan. The Zionism Movement In the late 19th and early 20th century, an organized religious and political movement known as Zionism emerged among Jews. Zionists wanted to reestablish a Jewish homeland in Palestine. Massive numbers of Jews immigrated to the ancient holy land and built settlements. Between 1882 and 1903, about 35,000 Jews relocated to Palestine. Another 40,000 settled in the area between 1904 and 1914. Many Jews living in Europe and elsewhere, fearing persecution during the Nazi reign, found refuge in Palestine and embraced Zionism. After the Holocaust and World War II ended, members of the Zionist movement primarily focused on creating an independent Jewish state. Arabs in Palestine resisted the Zionism movement, and tensions between the two groups continue. An Arab nationalist movement developed as a result. Israeli Independence The United Nations approved a plan to partition Palestine into a Jewish and Arab state in 1947, but the Arabs rejected it. In May 1948, Israel was officially declared an independent state with David Ben-Gurion, the head of the Jewish Agency, as the prime minister. While this historic event seemed to be a victory for Jews, it also marked the beginning of more violence with the Arabs. 1948 Arab-Israeli War Following the announcement of an independent Israel, five Arab nations‚ÄîEgypt, Jordan, Iraq, Syria, and Lebanon‚Äîimmediately invaded the region in what became known as the 1948 Arab-Israeli War. Civil war broke out throughout all of Israel, but a cease-fire agreement was reached in 1949. As part of the temporary armistice agreement, the West Bank became part of Jordan, and the Gaza Strip became Egyptian territory. How the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict Began Numerous wars and acts of violence between Arabs and Jews have ensued since the 1948 Arab-Israeli War. Some of these include: Suez Crisis: Relations between Israel and Egypt were rocky in the years following the 1948 war. In 1956, Egyptian president Gamal Abdel Nasser overtook and nationalized the Suez Canal, the important shipping waterway that connects the Red Sea to the Mediterranean Sea. With the help of British and French forces, Israel attacked the Sinai Peninsula and retook the Suez Canal. Six-Day War: In what started as a surprise attack, Israel in 1967 defeated Egypt, Jordan and Syria in six days. After this brief war, Israel took control of the Gaza Strip, Sinai Peninsula, the West Bank, and Golan Heights. These areas were considered ‚Äúoccupied‚Äù by Israel. Yom Kippur War: Hoping to catch the Israeli army off guard, in 1973 Egypt and Syria launched air strikes against Israel on the Holy Day of Yom Kippur. The fighting went on for two weeks, until the UN adopted a resolution to stop the war. Syria hoped to recapture the Golan Heights during this battle but was unsuccessful. In 1981, Israel annexed the Golan Heights, but Syria continued to claim it as territory. Lebanon War: In 1982, Israel invaded Lebanon and ejected the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO). Vanavond net na zeven uur heeft een gewapende schietpartij plaatsgevonden gericht op drie personen op de kruising van de Saincteclette en de 9de Linielaan, in het centrum van Brussel. 
 
Twee personen zijn daarbij overleden. 
Een derde, een taxichauffeur zou buiten levensgevaar zijn. 
 
De federale noodfase is afgekondigd deze avond om 21.13. 
 
Deze federale fase impliceert de mobilisatie van het nationaal crisiscentrum en van de nationale crisiscellen. 
 
Op dat moment is het dossier gefederaliseerd. 
De overname door het federaal parket kwam er omwille van het mogelijke terroristisch motief van de schietpartij. 
 
In de loop van de avond is er een opeising geweest op sociale media. Die boodschap was opgenomen door een persoon die zich identificeert als de aanslagpleger. 
Hij zegt zich te inspireren op de Islamitische Staat. 
 
Tijdens dezelfde boodschap werd de Zweedse nationaliteit van de slachtoffers aangehaald als mogelijk motief voor de daad. 
 
Op dit moment is er geen enkele aanwijzing dat de aanslag gelinkt zou zijn aan het Isra√´lisch-Palestijns conflict. 
 
Op basis van deze feiten en van de opeising zijn dringende veiligheidsmaatregelen genomen om de Zweedse supporters zo goed mogelijk te beschermen. 

Dreigingsniveau 4 voor het Brussels Hoofdstedelijk Gewest. 

Er wordt een actieve waakzaamheid gevraagd. Vermijd onnodige verplaatsingen.

2023 is officially in the books for MBR and it ended in a way that we never would have predicted. Since we purchased our car in 2015, our focus has been steadfast on running it in-house and racing it as a family team. In our first 8 years of ownership we have never had the desire to make our seat available for another driver at an event because we purchased the car for the sole purpose of wanting to race it ourselves. About a month ago we received an unexpected call from Antron Brown asking for a favor. He was in the midst of sorting through the logistics of getting a multi-race schedule finalized for Angelle Sampey‚Äôs Top Alcohol Dragster debut and they had one last hole in their schedule that needed to be filled because the car that she would be driving the rest of the year would not be available in Dallas due to a conflict with that event being the 2023 JEGS All Star race. To be fair, not only was that car not available, but none of the other proverbial front-running A/fuel cars in the class were available in Dallas due to the same reason. So Antron took a chance. Our team‚Äôs primary focuses have always been to have an immaculately-prepared racecar that is ready to run as soon as it arrives at the racetrack, to have a clean and professionally presented operation both on and off the track, and to provide a place where family, friends, and other racers can gather during the weekend that is a welcoming environment. Yes, we are constantly focused on finding ways to run quicker and faster, but on-track performance is a chase that will never stop and there will be variables at times that are out of our control. The other focuses listed above, however, are things that we can control and they are things that we are committed to every single time we leave the shop. This opportunity happened because Antron, his whole AB Motorsports Team, and Angelle all have the same values and vision as we do when it comes to what success looks like in the sport of drag racing. Antron and Angelle have each held the title of World Champion multiple times at the highest level of the sport and they know what it takes to win every single day. They showed up ready to make this event a success no matter what it took and they immersed themselves in both the team and our family from the moment we said ‚Äúlet‚Äôs do this.‚Äù For as long as this post is, it‚Äôs somehow only an anecdote that Angelle took out the #1 qualifier in round 1 and then eliminated national championship contender Tony Stewart in the second round of eliminations to record a semi-final finish in her first ever Top Alcohol Dragster race. She absolutely killed it while driving. We are northbound for the next day and a half heading back to Ohio and we‚Äôll be thinking about this weekend for a long time. 2024 will bring a new car and a new look for MBR, but the goals and values will remain the same. Antron, thank you for believing in us to give us a shot to launch your new AB Accelerate Program. It was an absolute honor. Angelle, thank you for your trust in our team and your care with our equipment. But more importantly, thank you for your incredible words in the video above. It is validation at the highest level that we are on the right path as we chase our dream. You both are part of the MBR family for life. #GOMBR

"Dialogue, Not Warfare, is the Path to Enduring Peace," asserts Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa in a conversation with Palestinian Ambassador to Sri Lanka, H.E. Dr. Zuhair Hamdallah. Mr. Sajith Premadasa emphasizes that the ongoing conflict between Israel and Palestine should be addressed through diplomatic negotiations to safeguard the well-being of citizens in both nations. He advocates for a lasting peace over temporary solutions, urging both countries to find a mutually agreeable resolution. Highlighting the grim reality reported by international media, Mr. Premadasa draws attention to the devastating toll the conflict has taken on innocent civilians, including women and children, in both Israel and Palestine. He extends his heartfelt condolences to those who have lost loved ones due to the hostilities. Also present at this crucial dialogue was Member of Parliament Imtiaz Bakir Makar. #SajithPremadasa #SamagiJanaBalawegaya #Srilanka #WhySajith #TeamSajith #Palestine #Isreal #Gaza #WAR
