When James Monroe was elected president in 1816, Washington, D.C., was still reeling with the aftermath of invasion. On August 24, 1814, British forces torched the White House and other federal buildings, casualties of the War of 1812. Yet in the aftermath of the conflict, national pride swelled. President Monroe hoped to embody the unity and economic growth of the ‚ÄúEra of Good Feelings.‚Äù In his vision, the reconstruction of the White House was a part of that unifying effort. Under the supervision of original architect James Hoban and commissioner Samuel Lane, the White House project moved along swiftly with a workforce of 190 free and enslaved laborers. President Monroe pressed for an even faster pace, demanding weekly reports from Colonel Lane and involving himself with the most minor details. The deadline of eight months set by President Monroe inflicted a heavy burden on the workers, but they worked diligently through the summer at his behest. As the White House progressed, the Monroes temporarily stayed in a rowhome at 2017 I Street NW. The Federal style brick house played eyewitness to James Monroe‚Äôs rise to the presidency and played host to his Inaugural reception. The president met with advisors in offices on the east side of the home, and First Lady Elizabeth Kortright Monroe entertained guests there with elegance and an affinity for French style. The I Street residence still stands, home to The Arts Club of Washington since 1918. President Monroe got his wish. The White House was ready in six months. On New Year‚Äôs Day 1818, President Monroe officially opened the mansion to the public for a three-hour reception. The interior reconstruction process continued into January 1820, but with President Monroe in residence, the People‚Äôs House projected American unity and resilience more than ever before.

SOUTH SUDAN AND KENYA EMBARK ON ESTABLISHING A JOINT COOPERATION COMMISSION JUBA - 16 October 2023---- President Kiir on Monday received a written message from Kenya's President William Samoei Ruto on issues of mutual concern between Juba and Nairobi. The message was conveyed to President Kiir by Kenyans Prime Cabinet Secretary and Foreign and Diaspora Affairs Musalia Mudavadi. Speaking to reporters Kenyans Prime Cabinet Secretary and Foreign and Diaspora Affairs Musalia Mudavadi commended President Kiir for unifying the people of South Sudan at the most critical time. Mudavadi noted that Kenya strongly believes that President Kiir has broad experience necessary for resolving the Sudanese conflict. South Sudan's Foreign Minister Dr. James Pitia Morgan assured the Kenyan delegation of President Kiir's resolve to continue working for peace and stability in South Sudan and the entire region. The meeting further discussed potential areas of shared interest within the framework of the East African Community.

text: Colombia demanded on Monday that Israel withdraw its ambassador from the South American nation, amid a row over the recent conflict in Gaza, the AFP reported. Colombian Foreign Minister Alvaro Leyva said the Israeli diplomatic envoy should ‚Äúat a minimum, apologize and leave‚Äù the country, a move that would be a blow to the previous strong relations between Bogota and Tel Aviv. Colombian President Gustavo Petro also caused an uproar on Saturday, Oct. 14, when he compared Israel's actions in Gaza to Nazi Germany's treatment of Jews. "This is what the Nazis said about the Jews. Democratic societies cannot allow Nazism to reestablish itself in international politics," Petro said about the impending Israeli military operation into Gaza. #CGTNAmerica

The Scottish physician and biologist John Boyd Orr emerged in the inter-war years as one of Britain's leading experts on nutrition. He maintained that many Britons were malnourished because their incomes were too low. Boyd Orr participated in the efforts in the League of Nations to achieve an international policy on nutrition. During the Second World War, he proposed the idea of a "world food plan" to President Franklin D. Roosevelt of the USA. In 1945 he was elected Director-General of the FAO (Food and Agriculture Organization), the first of the specialised organisations established under the United Nations. Food and prosperity for all people on earth led to peace, Boyd Orr argued. Boyd Orr was an ardent adherent of world organisation as a means of securing peace, and argued for a world government ruling according to rules of international law. The nations of the world were now so dependent on each other that they had to give up some of their sovereignty. Boyd Orr was elevated to the peerage for his national and international commitment. In 1949 he was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize "for his lifelong effort to conquer hunger and want, thereby helping to remove a major cause of military conflict and war." #WorldFoodDay

Konflik di Semenanjung Gaza yang sudah memasuki hari kesepuluh dilihat semakin meruncing. Peningkatan nyawa korban, jumlah yang cedera dan kerosakan harta benda tidak menampakkan kepada penyelesaian dalam masa terdekat krisis ini. Hari ini, di Dewan Rakyat, YAB Perdana Menteri Dato' Seri Anwar Ibrahim sekali lagi mengulangi dengan lebih tegas akan pendirian Malaysia yang berdiri teguh di belakang rakyat Palestin dan mahukan konflik ini menemui jalan penyelesaian dengan segera. Malaysia bersedia untuk membantu dari segenap cara dan perkara yang boleh mengurangkan beban rakyat Palestin. Perdana Menteri juga telah maklumkan di dalam dewan bahawa saya juga akan mewakili Malaysia untuk ke Mesyuarat Tergempar OIC di Jeddah pada 18 Oktober ini bagi membincangkan secara lebih lanjut mengenai isu Palestin ini. Ini akan disusuli dengan lawatan kerja Perdana Menteri ke Riyadh untuk Persidangan Asean-GCC pada 19 Oktober dan perjumpaan rasmi dengan Perdana Menteri Arab Saudi nanti. Pada masa sama, Malaysia juga sedang melihat kaedah dan cara tercepat dengan beberapa pihak untuk kita menghantar bantuan segera terutamanya bekalan makanan dan ubatan. Saya juga telah membuat panggilan telefon dengan beberapa rakan sejawatan dari negara lain seperti Indonesia, Brunei, Turkiye, UAE, Arab Saudi, Palestin, Iran, Setiausaha Agung United Nations, dan Pesuruhjaya Tinggi Kesatuan Eropah bagi mengangkat segala kebimbangan dan tindakan bersama yang boleh diambil. InsyaAllah kita cuba gerakkan segala bantuan yang boleh di segala peringkat dan keadaan. ------------------ The conflict in the Gaza Strip, which has entered its tenth day, continues to escalate. The increase in the number of injured victims and casualties and the damage to property does not indicate any resolution in the near future. Today, in the Dewan Rakyat, YAB Prime Minister @anwaribrahim_my once again reiterated Malaysia's stance that we stand firmly behind the Palestinian people and urge for this conflict to end immediately. Malaysia is ready to help in all ways that can ease the burden of the Palestinian people. The Prime Minister has also informed Dewan Rakyat that I will represent Malaysia at the OIC Extraordinary Meeting in Jeddah on 18 October to further discuss the Palestinian issue. This will be followed by the Prime Minister's working visit to Riyadh for the ASEAN-GCC Conference on October 19 and an official meeting with the Prime Minister of Saudi Arabia later. At the same time, Malaysia is also looking at the mechanism for us to immediately send aid, especially food and medicine supplies. I have also made phone calls with several counterparts such as Indonesia, Brunei, Turkiye, UAE, Saudi Arabia, Palestine, Iran, the Secretary General of the United Nations, and the High Commissioner of the European Union to raise our concerns and the possible joint actions that can be taken. InsyaAllah, we try to mobilize all assistance that we can at all levels. #wismaputra #doczam #MalaysiaMadani #prayforpalestine

People all over the world gathered this past weekend to protest Israel's attack on the Gaza Strip. Demonstrations were seen in the U.S., Algeria, Australia, and the Middle East, among others. Many had signs with information about the conflict and a call to end the attacks. The protests come after a week's worth of Israeli airstrikes on Gaza. More than 2,000 Palestinian civilians have been killed and more than 9,000 have been injured since October 7, while Israeli authorities say 1,400 of its population have died and 3,400 have been injured in the war. Currently people in Gaza have limited access to food, water, and electricity.

Yesterday, I had the privilege of addressing a congregation during a thanksgiving service held by the Izere Nation in honor of Prof. Danladi Abok Atu, the immediate past Secretary to Plateau State Government. The event took place at the St. Paul's Catholic Pastoral Area in Lamingo Gwafan, Jos North Local Government. I draw upon my extensive experience in peace building and conflict management to fulfill my current role. My focus is on fostering industrial harmony, a crucial element for President Tinubu's Renewed Hope Agenda. Throughout my journey in public service, I've strived to create an inclusive Plateau State free from discrimination, oppression, and injustice. This foundation has allowed all citizens to be active participants in governance, a cornerstone for trust and confidence in government operations. I firmly believe that building trust and confidence is vital, especially when faced with agitations, grievances, or differences that could otherwise be exploited. President Bola Tinubu's vision is to develop Nigeria by encouraging dedicated public and private sector workers. This was evident in our swift response to a recent labor strike threat, which we successfully averted through dialogue. During the event, I expressed my gratitude to Prof. Danladi Abok Atu for his diligent work in implementing the Rescue Agenda of my administration. I also assured the people of Plateau State that I would continue to advocate for the state's interests within the Federal Government, striving to attract programs and projects through every available means. Catholic Archbishop of Jos, Ishaya Audu, acknowledged Prof. Atu's visionary leadership and his commitment to serving the people. He encouraged me to advocate for critical issues such as infrastructure, education, security, and other entitlements of Plateau State as a member of the Federal Executive Council. In a heartfelt homily, Msgnr Prof. Cletus Gotan emphasized the importance of service to the people as service to God, urging public officeholders to fulfill their mandates with dedication and a deep sense of moral responsibility. The large gathering at the event demonstrated Prof. Atu's successful collaboration with people from all walks of life, who came together to offer their thanks to God. The paramount ruler of the Izere Nation, Adagwom Izere Dr. Isaac Wakili, highlighted Prof. Atu's contributions to the community's development and his unwavering integrity, which brought honor to the Chiefdom. Prof. Danladi Abok Atu, the guest of honor, expressed his gratitude to God for the opportunity to serve the public over the years, including his recent role as the Secretary to Plateau State Government under my administration. He commended me for my commitment to peace, competence, compassion, and integrity. He vowed to maintain the trust placed in him and encouraged former appointees to unite in building a robust political structure for effective service. The event was graced by dignitaries from both within and outside the state, including Mallam Balarabe Abbas Lawal, Minister Designate and former Secretary to Kaduna State Government. Following the event, I hosted some of my former appointees at my residence, including commissioners, Heads of Boards and Parastatals, and members of the House of Assembly.

He also called for the South African government to cancel the flight permits of Israeli national air carrier El-Al. South Africa has close relations with Palestine. Nelson Mandela toured Gaza in 1999 and urged Israel to withdraw from all the areas it occupied after the 1967 war with neighboring Arab states, and in particular to withdraw completely from the Golan Heights, from south Lebanon and from the West Bank. How Do Shaivites Regard Other Faiths? Religious beliefs are manifold and different. Shaivites, understanding the strength of this diversity, wholeheartedly respect and encourage all who believe in God. They honor the fact that Truth is one, paths are many. Since the inner intent of all religions is to bind man back to God, Shaivite Hindus seek not to interfere with anyone‚Äôs faith or practice. We believe that there is no exclusive path, no one way for all. Shaivites profoundly know that God Shiva is the same Supreme Being in whom peoples of all faiths find solace, peace and liberation. Nonetheless, we realize that all religions are not the same. Each has its unique beliefs, practices, goals and paths of attainment, and the doctrines of one often conflict with those of another. Even this should never be cause for religious tension or intolerance. Shaivites respect all religious traditions and the people within them. They know that good citizens and stable societies are created from groups of religious people. Shaivite leaders support and participate in ecumenical gatherings with all religions. Still, Shaivites defend their faith, proceed contentedly with their practices and avoid the enchantment of other ways, be they ancient or modern. The Vedas explain, ‚ÄúLet us have concord with our own people, and concord with people who are strangers to us. Asvins, create between us and the strangers a unity of hearts.‚Äù Aum Namah Shivaya. JUST IN: President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. is headed to Saudi Arabia for the first Asean-Gulf Cooperation Council Summit, according to DFA Asec. Daniel Espiritu. Espiritu said that a bilateral meeting between the PH and Saudi Arabia is possible, where Marcos can pitch the Maharlika Investment Fund. Regional and international issues will also be discussed, including conflicts in the Middle East. However, Espiritu noted that none of the countries Marcos will be meeting are directly involved with the conflict. Espiritu explained that the meeting will focus on political security and the economy. The Asean and the GCC are also set to explore areas of cooperation in counterterrorism. The President will leave the Philippines later this week. Marcos is also set to meet with the Filipino community in Saudi Arabia. He is set to meet with business leaders, but Espiritu said that the details are still being finalized. Marcos will also discuss labor reforms. This includes the compensation of 10,000 OFWs. Espiritu said that it is an "official trip" for Marcos. | via Jean Mangaluz, INQUIRER.net

text: Spiritual Enemies In a battle, it is imperative to identify your enemy. If you are not aware of the point of your attack, you are vulnerable. Paul had many enemies. Some resented him, others hated him, and others wanted to kill him. Some, who were supposedly on his side, sought to harm him and his ministry (Acts 9:23; Phil. 1:17; 2 Tim. 1:15; 1 Tim. 1:20; 2 Tim. 4:14). In spite of the persecution he faced, Paul never lost sight of his real enemy. Paul was wary of Satan. When people attacked him, he knew they were not his real opponents. They were simply unwitting instruments of the spiritual forces of darkness. When you meet opposition to your faith, your first reaction may be anger toward your antagonist. This may divert your attention from the deeper, spiritual dimensions of your conflict. Your adversary may be hopelessly into sin. Rather than retaliating, you should immediately and earnestly intercede for that person. Your opponent‚Äôs hostility is your invitation to become involved in God‚Äôs redemptive work to free him or her from spiritual oppression. Be alert to the spiritual warfare around you. It is real and potentially destructive to you and those you care about. Knowing your real foe will protect you from bitterness and unforgiveness. Your hope lies in the reality that ‚ÄúHe who is in you is greater than he who is in the world‚Äù (1 John 4:4). Do not place your hope in humanity, but steadfastly trust in the One who has already defeated your enemy. For we do not wrestle against flesh and blood, but against principalities, against powers, against the rulers of the darkness of this age, against spiritual hosts of wickedness in the heavenly places. Ephesians 6:12 Blackaby Ministries

text: Governor Radda Inaugurates Twin Court Chambers, Presents Official Cars to 6 Katsina Judges To herald the 2023/24 legal year in Katsina State, Governor Dikko Umaru Radda, on Monday, commissioned a newly-constructed twin court chambers for the State's High Court judges. The event took place at the Headquarters of the Katsina State High Court of Justice. During the inauguration of the court complex named after Justice Amiru Sanusi, six brand-new Toyota jeeps were also presented by Governor Radda to the four recently-sworn in judges of the Katsina High Court, and two Khadis of the State's Shariah Court of Appeal. In his address at the ceremony, the Katsina State helmsman emphasized the need for the judiciary to join hands with the executive and legislature, in ensuring that criminals are appropriately punish for offences committed. He however, appreciated the Katsina High Court in responding to security challenges in the State, by establishing Community and Conflict Resolution Centres, across the State. This, he said, was in line with the policy of his administration' in addressing the lingering security challenges bedeviling Katsina, and entire North West, in general. Mallam Radda admitted that the recent amendment of the State Local Government Law has provided for the establishment of at least one Dispute and Conflict Resolution Centre at a major market in each of the 34 local government areas of the State. The measure, according to the Governor, would allow security agencies and courts to attend to the more serious and demanding legal cases. He therefore, called on all those in Katsina's justice sector to give necessary support and legal backing to the recently-inaugurated State Community Watch Corps, to effectively operate. He said: "Indeed, the constitutional role of the judiciary can only be discharged effectively if its independence is guaranteed". On her part, the State's Attorney General and Commissioner for Justice, Barrister Fadila Mohammed Dikko, said in the just-outgone legal year, the Public Prosecution Department of their Ministry treated 533 case dairies received for legal advice. Of the treated cases, she said 48 judgements were passed at the State High Court, alongside with 23 others at the appellate courts. Bar. Dikko appreciated Governor Radda for granting an approval to their Ministry to recruit additional state counsel and organize capacity-building training to improve their ability. Signed: Ibrahim Kaula Mohammed, CPS to Katsina Governor. October 16th, 2023.

Our wounded parts want to hold onto small things and use them as proof that we're not lovable, not good enough, that our partners are out to get us. A big part of learning to be happy in relationship is noticing when our ego wants to indulge in our story of brokenness and choosing to let go instead. What do I mean by "indulging in a story of brokenness"? When we've been wounded, our ego builds an identity around it. We may not even realize that we're carrying around stories of being unworthy or unlovable, or that we unconsciously feel drawn to friction, tension, or drama in relationship. I see Conscious Relationship as the practice of learning to cultivate, harness and carefully direct our energy in a positive direction. When we're wired to fight, defend, poke and prod or fall into self-pity - it actually takes a lot of energetic practice to let go in the moments where we're feeling activated and have an opportunity to feed the story. Many of us say we want harmony, but actually we quite enjoy conflict on some level and we're not being honest with ourselves about that. Maybe what we really enjoy is just the energy - the intensity of feeling or the attention we're receiving. And so we get to ask ourselves - is this how I want to use my energy? Do I need to respond to the thing my partner just said or did with more fire? Do I want to spend my energy on arguing, being right, proving a point, or can I channel this energy back into my heart and express myself in a way that will create an opportunity to deepen in love? Choosing peace isn't as simple as saying we want it. Choosing peace is a life-long practice of self-observation, dancing with energy and choosing where to put it. Taking deep breaths, Seeing our partners heart, Responding with a loving statement rather than being defensive (even when you're annoyed), or simply finding a tree to admire ... are all ways to ground into the present moment and realize that life is too precious to spend wasting our energy away on things that don't matter. üåø @sheleanaaiyana *This post isn't directed to those in abusive dynamics.*

It was taken a few weeks ago when he turned 6. The second image is a mugshot of Joseph M Czuba, the 71 year old landlord who stabbed Wadea and his mother in their home in Illinois yesterday. She survived but is in serious condition. He died from his injuries. Officers have enough evidence to charge Czuba with a hate crime and announce that he targeted Wadea and his mother "for being Muslim and the ongoing Middle Eastern conflict involving Hamas and Israelis". Over the last few days, Jews have been reaching out to me because they say they feel scared. And I get it. Situations like this always cause a rise in Antisemitism. BUT IT WORKS BOTH WAYS. Situations like this always cause a rise in Islamophobia too. And the first child to die on US/UK soil since the war started is a Palestinian one. I encourage all my Jewish friends to take a long hard look at this photograph and remember his name the next time you feel scared and use that as a means to justify your Zionism. Also, do not ever forget who colonised Palestine in the late 19th/early 20th century. Do not ever forget who gave the land (like it was theirs to give) to make way for an Israeli state. Do not ever forget which countries profit the most from the sales of arms and who are invested in maintaining a "strong friendship" with a country in the Middle East to suit its own needs. And most of all do not forget the role we all play in encouraging despicable human beings like Czuba to murder innocent children in order to make himself feel better. We aimed to amplify their voices on a global scale and bring attention to their plight. The marathon was themed as "The Right to Freedom of Movement," a message we strongly believe in and desire to convey to the world. Our goal was to shed light on the constraints placed on the freedom of movement in #Palestine and underscore the daily challenges that the Palestinians encounter in their pursuit of fundamental rights. Our dedication to upholding human rights and unwavering support for the Palestinian people remain resolute. I urge all individuals with the means and influence to join us in raising awareness about this issue. Together, we can exert pressure on the international community to take action and bring an end to the heart-wrenching conflict that continues to afflict our hearts.

You‚Äôre not seeing double! We took down the original announcement for our lab opening because of a last-minute scheduling conflict. Here is the updated info: Our new archaeology facility, the Mary C. Beaudry Community Archaeology Center, is about to open to the public, and we are celebrating with YOU! Join us on Wednesday, October 25 from 9am-5pm, for an open house event. Meet the team, take a behind-the-scenes tour of our new 4,000 square foot facility, and be the first to see our new exhibit on the archaeology of the 1630s James Garrett house site in Charlestown. Our new facility is in the same building we were in before, but down a floor, at the City of Boston Archival Center, 201 Rivermoor Street, in the West Roxbury neighborhood of Boston. There will be a ribbon cutting with special guests at 9am. Our new facility features: -two processing laboratories -an artifact digitizing lab with state-of-the-art 3D scanners, printers, and photography equipment -our artifact repository of over 1,000,000 artifacts from dozens of ancient and historical sites in Boston -an extensive historical ceramic and lithic raw material comparative type collection -a specialized wet laboratory -a research library featuring over 2,000 reference books and archaeological reports -museum exhibit spaces, an amazing new mural, and some of the nicest and most knowledgeable archaeologists around. We‚Äôre also neighbors to the amazing City Archives team as well as archivists and collections librarians from the BPDA and Boston Public Library, so there‚Äôs plenty to do, see, and research while you‚Äôre here. Can‚Äôt make it on the 25th? Our exhibits will be open and viewable year-round during normal business hours on the first floor of the City of Boston Archival Center at 201 Rivermoor Street. Our new facility features glass walls so you can stop by anytime to see what we are working on, but please email in advance to schedule research and collections access at archaeology@boston.gov

STAY AT PEACE: Let things break. Many times the Universe kindly allows it even though our ego doesn't understand it. Stop trying to keep them stuck if their cycle is over. Stay at peace. Let people get angry. Let them criticize you... totally, they are different beings and their reaction is not your problem. Stay at peace. Let it all fall apart, and don't worry about after. Everything is a constant coming and going, taking and letting go... learn wisely from nature; from the waves of the sea... and learn from yourself; of your breath... Stay at peace. It is the restless mind that lashes out. Where will I go? To do? No one has ever been lost on the way, no one was left without shelter. In the Universe there is always a path, a guide, a route. Stay at peace. What is meant to go will go anyway. What has to stay will remain. Keep it in mind. Stay at peace. As much as you try to retain all the air in your lungs, you will have to release it or else the same retained air will drown you. Stay at peace. Too much effort, too much turbulence is never a good sign... too much effort and turbulence is a sign of conflict with the Universe. Stay at peace. Relationships, jobs, home, family, friends and great loves... Surrender everything to Earth and Heaven. When you can take care and protect, water with love, attend and feed, contemplate and enjoy, pray and dance but then... let what should bloom and the dry leaves tear themselves away. Stay at peace. What goes away always leaves room for something new: they are the Universal Laws... And never think that there is nothing good for you anymore, you just have to stop containing what you have to let go. Stay at peace. Remember that every process is a learning experience for your life. Although some are less pleasant than others, their goal will always be to teach you. Receive every lesson with LOVE. Stay at peace. Only when your journey ends, then the possibilities end, but only until then. So let it all fall apart, let go, let be. Nothing is static... the Universe is in constant motion... üñämariomelito Love and Light, Michelle Price

7 practical lessons from the book "People Can't Drive You Crazy if You Don't Give Them the Keys" by Mike Bechtle "People Can't Drive You Crazy if You Don't Give Them the Keys" is a self-help book written by Mike Bechtle. The book explores the concept of personal boundaries and how they can be instrumental in maintaining healthy relationships and managing difficult people. 1. Take responsibility for your own emotions One of the key lessons from the book is that we have control over our own emotions and reactions. We often give others the power to affect our mood and well-being, but in reality, it is up to us how we choose to respond. By taking responsibility for our own emotions, we can maintain a sense of peace and control in our lives. 2. Set healthy boundaries Setting boundaries is crucial in maintaining healthy relationships. The book emphasizes the importance of establishing clear boundaries with others, both in terms of what we will and will not tolerate. By doing so, we can protect ourselves from unnecessary stress and conflict, and create healthier dynamics in our relationships. 3. Practice empathy and understanding The book encourages us to practice empathy and understanding towards others. It reminds us that everyone has their own struggles, insecurities, and challenges. By trying to understand where others are coming from, we can foster compassion and build stronger connections with them. 4. Choose your battles wisely Not every situation requires a response or confrontation. The book advises us to choose our battles wisely and consider whether it is worth engaging in conflict or getting upset over minor issues. By prioritizing what truly matters, we can conserve our energy and focus on more important aspects of our lives. 5. Communicate effectively Effective communication is essential in any relationship. The book emphasizes the importance of expressing our thoughts and feelings clearly and assertively, while also being open to listening to others. By improving our communication skills, we can avoid misunderstandings, resolve conflicts, and build stronger connections with those around us. 6. Practice self-care Taking care of ourselves is crucial in maintaining our mental and emotional well-being. The book emphasizes the importance of self-care and encourages us to prioritize activities that recharge and rejuvenate us. By practising self-care, we can better manage stress, improve our overall happiness, and be more resilient in dealing with challenging situations. 7. Focus on what you can control Lastly, the book reminds us to focus on what we can control rather than getting caught up in things beyond our influence. By directing our energy towards the things we have power over, we can avoid unnecessary frustration and maintain a sense of peace and balance in our lives. Follow Readers Hub for more book recommendations and reviews

RANK: FIRST LIEUTENANT (RANK AT PRESENTATION: CAPTAIN; HIGHEST RANK: COLONEL) CONFLICT/ERA: VIETNAM WAR UNIT/COMMAND: ARMY ELEMENT, U.S. MILITARY ASSISTANCE COMMAND MILITARY SERVICE BRANCH: U.S. ARMY MEDAL OF HONOR ACTION DATE: MARCH 9, 1968 MEDAL OF HONOR ACTION PLACE: KIEN PHONG PROVINCE, REPUBLIC OF VIETNAM CITATION For conspicuous gallantry and intrepidity in action at the risk of his life above and beyond the call of duty. Capt. Jacobs (then 1st Lt.), Infantry, distinguished himself while serving as assistant battalion adviser, 2d Battalion, 16th Infantry, 9th Infantry Division, Army of the Republic of Vietnam. The 2d Battalion was advancing to contact when it came under intense heavy machine-gun and mortar fire from a Viet Cong battalion positioned in well-fortified bunkers. As the 2d Battalion deployed into attack formation, its advance was halted by devastating fire. Capt. Jacobs, with the command element of the lead company, called for and directed air strikes on the enemy positions to facilitate a renewed attack. Due to the intensity of the enemy fire and heavy casualties to the command group, including the company commander, the attack stopped and the friendly troops became disorganized. Although wounded by mortar fragments, Capt. Jacobs assumed command of the allied company, ordered a withdrawal from the exposed position, and established a defensive perimeter. Despite profuse bleeding from head wounds which impaired his vision, Capt. Jacobs, with complete disregard for his safety, returned under intense fire to evacuate a seriously wounded adviser to the safety of a wooded area where he administered lifesaving first aid. He then returned through heavy automatic-weapons fire to evacuate the wounded company commander. Capt. Jacobs made repeated trips across the fire-swept, open rice paddies, evacuating wounded and their weapons. On three separate occasions, Capt. Jacobs contacted and drove off Viet Cong squads who were searching for allied wounded and weapons, single-handedly killing three and wounding several others. His gallant actions and extraordinary heroism saved the lives of one U.S. adviser and 13 allied soldiers. Through his effort the allied company was restored to an effective fighting unit and prevented defeat of the friendly forces by a strong and determined enemy. Capt. Jacobs, by his gallantry and bravery in action in the highest traditions of the military service, has reflected great credit upon himself, his unit, and the U.S. Army.

DAILY MANNA TUESDAY OCTOBER 17, 2023 NO BOUNDARIES KEY VERSE: ‚ÄúThus saith the LORD; For three transgressions of Judah, and for four, I will not turn away the punishment thereof; because they have despised the law of the LORD, and have not kept his commandments, and their lies caused them to err, after the which their fathers have walked‚Äù (Amos 2:4). TEXT: AMOS 2:1-5 All men are equal before God. As the ultimate Judge of all creations, God does not consider background, colour, race or social status as a condition for determining the end of all men. As shown in Proverbs 3:1, God requires all men irrespective of where they come from not to forget His law. This forms the fulcrum of today‚Äôs text. God spoke to Prophet Amos about His resolve to judge Moab and Judah based on their transgressions. As for Moab, God promised not to ‚Äúturn away the punishment thereof; because he burned the bones of the king of Edom into lime‚Äù. In the case of Judah, God frowned at their flagrant disregard of His words. As a result, He insisted on bringing punishment upon them ‚Äúbecause they have despised the law of the LORD, and have not kept his commandments‚Ä¶‚Äù Moab was a Gentile nation, which was constantly in conflict with the Israelites. Amos proclaimed Moab‚Äôs doom for seizing and burning the king of Edom. In its case, Judah was out of the 12 tribes that constituted Israel. Judah, like Moab, transgressed the word of the Lord. Even though Judah was a tribe of Israel, God did not spare them. Rather, He promised to send fire upon Judah and devour the palaces of Jerusalem for despising His laws. This account reveals that God is neither of the Jews nor of the Gentiles exclusively. He is the God of all creation. He never discriminates based on background, colour, ethnicity, political class or social status. He is the ultimate Judge, who determines the actions and deeds of all men purely based on equity, fairness and justice. He demands outright compliance with His word as a condition for walking with Him and ultimately escaping eternal damnation. THOUGHT FOR THE DAY: God‚Äôs judgment does not respect a sinner‚Äôs status. If you've seen our last videos, you know that we don't have many photos in the country of Chad because photos in certain areas are frowned upon. But we wanted to share a few of our memories along with a little about what we learned about the incredible people of Chad. First, a little info about the country. Chad is a landlocked country in Central Africa that has a deep and complex history. It's at the crossroads of the Saharan and sub-Saharan regions, and encompasses deserts, savannahs, and mountains. The country gained independence in 1960, but its history has been marred by political instability and conflict, which continue to impact it today. Chad is currently facing daily internal conflict and security challenges. A long civil war, intermittent rebellions, and ethnic tensions have plagued the country, leading to instability and displacement of populations. The Chadian people are stuck in the middle of all this conflict. Despite the many challenges people face, Chad is home to a resilient and diverse population known for its warmth and hospitality. The Chadian people are composed of over 200 different ethnic groups, and are known for their strong sense of community, often coming together in times of need. Despite the ongoing conflicts, they continue to strive for a better future, working towards peace, stability, and development for their nation. Even though we didn't speak their language (there are actually 100+ different local languages spoken in Chad in addition to French!), we met so many incredibly friendly people who went out of their way to welcome us to their country. People here have so much joy and hope despite the difficulties many of them face! So thankful to be able to meet some of these incredible people while in Chad!!

7 practical lessons from the book "People Can't Drive You Crazy if You Don't Give Them the Keys" by Mike Bechtle "People Can't Drive You Crazy if You Don't Give Them the Keys" is a self-help book written by Mike Bechtle. The book explores the concept of personal boundaries and how they can be instrumental in maintaining healthy relationships and managing difficult people. 1. Take responsibility for your own emotions One of the key lessons from the book is that we have control over our own emotions and reactions. We often give others the power to affect our mood and well-being, but in reality, it is up to us how we choose to respond. By taking responsibility for our own emotions, we can maintain a sense of peace and control in our lives. 2. Set healthy boundaries Setting boundaries is crucial in maintaining healthy relationships. The book emphasizes the importance of establishing clear boundaries with others, both in terms of what we will and will not tolerate. By doing so, we can protect ourselves from unnecessary stress and conflict, and create healthier dynamics in our relationships. 3. Practice empathy and understanding The book encourages us to practice empathy and understanding towards others. It reminds us that everyone has their own struggles, insecurities, and challenges. By trying to understand where others are coming from, we can foster compassion and build stronger connections with them. 4. Choose your battles wisely Not every situation requires a response or confrontation. The book advises us to choose our battles wisely and consider whether it is worth engaging in conflict or getting upset over minor issues. By prioritizing what truly matters, we can conserve our energy and focus on more important aspects of our lives. 5. Communicate effectively Effective communication is essential in any relationship. The book emphasizes the importance of expressing our thoughts and feelings clearly and assertively, while also being open to listening to others. By improving our communication skills, we can avoid misunderstandings, resolve conflicts, and build stronger connections with those around us. 6. Practice self-care Taking care of ourselves is crucial in maintaining our mental and emotional well-being. The book emphasizes the importance of self-care and encourages us to prioritize activities that recharge and rejuvenate us. By practising self-care, we can better manage stress, improve our overall happiness, and be more resilient in dealing with challenging situations. 7. Focus on what you can control Lastly, the book reminds us to focus on what we can control rather than getting caught up in things beyond our influence. By directing our energy towards the things we have power over, we can avoid unnecessary frustration and maintain a sense of peace and balance in our lives. Follow Readers Hub for more book recommendations and reviews

ùêíùêÄùêí ùê´ùêÆùê•ùêû ùê¶ùêûùêß'ùê¨ ùêÅùêöùêùùê¶ùê¢ùêßùê≠ùê®ùêß, ùêíùêéùêçùêÄùêáùêÅùêí ùê´ùêûùê≠ùêöùê¢ùêß ùê∞ùê®ùê¶ùêûùêß'ùê¨ ùêúùê´ùê®ùê∞ùêß School of Advanced Studies (SAS) men's team and School of Nursing, Allied Health, and Biological Sciences (SONAHBS) women's team dominated the pack to reign as champions of the 2023 SLU Intramurals badminton competition held at Prince Bernhard Gymnasium, Sunday, October 15. ùë∂ùíñùíïùíîùíéùíÇùíìùíïùíäùíèùíà ùíïùíâùíÜ ùíáùíäùíÜùíçùíÖ The SAS trio headed by Norman Elpa, bagged wins in the singles A, singles B, and doubles category by demonstrating powerful smashes and elite athleticism around the court, accumulating an undefeated 6-0 record to top the Men's division leaderboard. "Kahit kulang yung preparation namin as a team, naibigay pa rin namin yung best namin at nakapagchampion pa kami", Elpa said regarding the struggles they faced in preparing for the competition. Elpa, together with his teammates faced tough challenges against the School of Teacher Education and Liberal Arts (STELA), and the School of Engineering and Architecture (SEA), both placed second and third respectively as they got outsmarted with mastery and finesse. "Yung sa STELA, sana makabawi sila next year kasi talagang kulang din sila sa preparation, talagang nagkulang kami and considering na nagkaroon ng conflict sa schedule nila, at least naibigay pa rin nila yung best nila during the games," Elpa added on his role as a coach for STELA. ùë©ùíÇùíÑùíå-ùíïùíê-ùíÉùíÇùíÑùíå ùíÑùíâùíÇùíéùíëùíäùíêùíèùíî In the women's division, the trio of Faith Amugauan, Azzaleah Krizlee Dugayon, and Mika Ella Tabuso of the School of Allied Health and Biological Sciences' (SONAHBS) crushed the competition with their racket control and in-court awareness, finishing with an unrivaled record of 6-0, bagging their second straight women's badminton championship. "Teamwork talaga iyong pinaka-una naming tinatak sa isip naming tatlo kasi hindi namin mababack-to-back 'to kung wala kaming teamwork, and even last intramurals ganoon din po iyong mindset namin kaya masaya po kami na nadefend po namin iyong title namin," said Amugauan. The women's badminton competition was a tight race as STELA landed second, suffering major losses in favor of the champions, while SEA finished third, after losing a crucial women's doubles match against STELA. There are outlaw states whose intentions are demonstrably evil, whether supporting terrorism or developing nuclear, biological and chemical weapons which will be used to threaten us. Israel showed the way by its pre-emptive strike to destroy Iraq's nuclear potential in the early eighties. Just imagine what would have been the prospects for peace in the Middle East if Iraq had acquired nuclear weapons. The use of force in this way is never to be undertaken lightly. The risks will always be great. But if we give up the option of pre-emptive action, we deprive ourselves of the only language which evil regimes understand and the only effective measure to protect ourselves from their schemes. ____ 1995 Aug 4 Fr, Margaret Thatcher. Read‚Ä¶this not a visual post! ‚Ä¶Spot on! - From Jonathan CooküëáüèΩ (on twitter/X, whatever). (the image for obvious sm reasons): The missing context for what's happening in Gaza is that Israel has been working night and day to ethnically cleanse the Palestinian people from their homeland since even before Israel become a state ‚Äì when it was known as the Zionist movement. Israel didn't just cleanse Palestinians in 1948, when it was founded as a Western colonial project, and again under cover of a regional war in 1967. It also worked to ethnically cleanse Palestinians every day between those dates and afterwards. The aim was to move them off their historic lands, and either expel them beyond Israel‚Äôs new, expanded borders or concentrate them into small ghettoes inside those borders ‚Äì as a holding measure until they could be expelled outside the borders. The 'settler' project, as we call it, is a misnomer. It's really Israel's ethnic cleansing programme. Israel even has a special word for it in Hebrew: 'Judaisation', or making the land Jewish. It is official government policy. Gaza was the largest of the Palestinian reservations created by Israel's ethnic cleansing programme, and the most overcrowded. To stop the inhabitants spilling out, Israel built a fence-barrier in the early 1990s to pen them in. Then when policing became too hard from within the prison, Israel pulled back in 2005 to the outer perimeter barrier. New technology allowed Israel to besiege Gaza remotely by land, sea and air in 2007, limiting the entry of food and vital items like medicine and cement for construction. Automated gun towers shot anyone who came near the fence. The navy patrolled the sea, stopping boats straying more than a kilometre or two off shore. And drones watched 24 hours a day from the sky. The people of Gaza were sealed in and largely forgotten, except when they lobbed a few rockets over the fence ‚Äì to international indignation. If they fired too many rockets, Israel bombed them mercilessly and occasionally launched a ground invasion. The rocket threat was increasingly neutralised by a rocket interception system, paid for by the US, called Iron Dome. Palestinians tried to be more inventive in finding ways to break out of their prison. They built tunnels. But Israel found ways to identify those that ran close to the fence and destroyed them. Palestinians tried to get attention by protesting en masse at the fence. Israeli snipers were ordered to shoot them in the legs, leading to thousands of amputees. The 'deterrence' seemed to work. Israel could once again sit back and let the Palestinians rot in Gaza. 'Quiet' had been restored. Until, that is, last weekend when Hamas broke out briefly and ran amok, killing civilians and soldiers alike. So Israel now needs a new policy. It looks like the ethnic cleansing programme is being applied to Gaza anew. The half of the population in the enclave's north is being herded south, where there are not the resources to cope with them. And even if there were, Israel has cut off food, water and power to everyone in Gaza. The enclave is quickly becoming a pressure cooker. The pressure is meant to build on Egypt to allow the Palestinians entry into Sinai on 'humanitarian' grounds. Whatever the media are telling you, the 'conflict' ‚Äì that is, Israel's cleansing programme ‚Äì started long before Hamas appeared on the scene. In fact, Hamas emerged very late, as the predictable response to Israel's violent colonisation project. And no turning point was reached a week ago. This has all been playing out in slow motion for more than 100 years. Ignore the fake news. Israel isn't defending itself. It's enforcing its right to continue ethnically cleansing Palestinians.

text: In 1244 Henry III decided to finish Prince Dafydd of Wales once and for all. He raised a great army at Chester and marched into Gwynedd, hoping to crush Dafydd's revolt and strengthen the royal castle at Deganwy. All the chronicle sources, Welsh and English, agree this was a particularly vicious campaign. The chronicles tally with the records of Henry's administration, which contain orders to impose a trade embargo and naval blockade on North Wales. By one means or another, military conquest or economic stranglehold, Henry was determined to get a result. The war that followed was a bloody, laborious, expensive mess. Henry's commissariat failed to provide his soldiers with adequate food or winter gear, which meant they died like flies. A particularly eloquent letter, written by one of Henry's nobles, describes men camped on the bare slopes of Deganwy, exposed to rain, cold and furious Welsh guerilla attacks. Both sides behaved with utter savagery. Henry revived the custom of head-taking, whereby his soldiers were paid a bounty of twopence for the head of every slaughtered Welshman. At one point, Matthew Paris notes, a hundred heads were brought into camp. The Welsh, for their part, chopped up English prisoners on the banks of the River Conwy, within sight of their comrades. Afterwards the body parts were thrown into the water, to mingle with the bloated corpses and overturned supply ships. To get supplies, Henry ordered a fleet from Ireland. An Irish army landed on Anglesey, where it burnt the crops and massacred the populace. This, wrote Paris, was because the Irish had ‚Äúan old hatred‚Äù against the Welsh. By destroying the harvest, Henry stupidly deprived himself of the means of feeding his soldiers. After several weeks of this hell, Henry withdrew to England and left his captains to finish the job. The conflict ground on for another two years, until Gwynedd was virtually burnt and blasted out of existence. His enemy, Prince Dafydd, died in February 1246. He was only 33, and there were rumours of poison, since his hair and teeth fell out. Yet Dafydd could just as easily have succumbed to disease or malnutrition, like so many of his people. It really shouldn't have come to this: Dafydd was Henry's nephew, a grandson of King John, and married to an English noblewoman, Isabella de Braose. The whole thrust of Llywelyn the Great's policy was to produce an heir with close ties to the English court, to avoid just this type of conflict. But it happened anyway. Dafydd's early death left a power vacuum in Gwynedd. It was quickly filled by his nephews, Llywelyn and Owain Goch, sons of his half-brother Gruffudd. They were still young, and untried, and inherited a seemingly impossible situation. The relentless pressure of Henry's blockade was starting to tell. Two prominent Welsh nobles, key supporters of Llywelyn the Great and Dafydd, had already defected to the royal army. The last effective resistance was in Ceredigion, West Wales, not Gwynedd. Here, one Maelgwn Fychan held out until the end of August 1246, when he was escorted to the king by Gruffudd ap Gwenwynwyn. The very last resistance was offered by Maelgwn's steward, described as an old man, until he was captured on 6 November. And that, apparently, was it. It looked as though Henry III had conquered the Welsh. The king certainly thought he had imposed his power on Gwynedd: in subsequent years he referred to his 'new conquest' of North Wales. Yet Henry is not remembered as the conqueror of Wales. So how did it all unravel for him? Let's find out...

I have learned with utmost sadness about the passing of the former President of Finland, H.E. Martti Ahtisaari, a friend of the Namibian liberation struggle and a leading peacemaker who played through the United Nations a pivotal role in midwifing the birth of a new Namibia. The history of Martti Athissari is incomplete without Namibia, a country he was associated with in the many roles that he occupied. First through his appointment as a senator to the Council of the United Nations Institute for Namibia (UNIN) in 1975, a position which later led to his appointment in 1978 by United Nations Secretary General Kurt Waldheim as the Special Representative of the Secretary General for Namibia. In 1989, he was appointed by the United Nations Secretary General to assume the difficult task as the leader of the United Nations Transition Assistance Group (UNTAG) in Namibia, which was globally hailed as a model in dealing with complex transitions from conflict to peace. Major parts in the history of Namibia would be incomplete without the name of former President Ahtisaari. As a Fin, former President Ahtisaari understood fully our quest for freedom and justice. Therefore, in the roles of diplomat, negotiator, peacekeeper and blue helmet, former President Ahtisaari served the Namibian people who were seeking self-determination and justice with flying colors. As an icon in the imagination of the Namibian people, President Ahtisaari was inscribed as an honorary citizen of the Republic of Namibia, with streets and schools having been named after him in remembrance and in celebration of his exceptional deeds in the birth of a free Namibia. Therefore, today, we are not only mourning the loss of former President Ahtisaari, a friend and one of us, but we are also reaffirming the rich legacy of peace and the outstanding international public service of a Nobel peace laureate with an indelible association with Namibia. On behalf of the people and the Government of the Republic of Namibia, I wish to extend sincere condolences to the Ahtisaari family and our sister country, Finland. May His Soul Rest in Peace Hage G. Geingob

The 2023 Sunnyside High School Alumni Wall of Fame Inductees were recognized before kick-off at the Homecoming Football Game. Today we will be sharing their stories and hope you will help us congratulate them on their induction! First up is Sandra Rasheed, Class of 1990! Of her time in the Sunnyside School District, she demonstrated an insatiable thrust for knowledge, and took on a diverse range of subject and extracurricular activities. Her favorite memories of this time include taking a Humanities class with Mrs. Adiele who led archaeological excavations in the schoolyard. Following graduation, she attended Eastern Washington University where she earned a Bachelors of Arts in English Literature and completed a Master‚Äôs Degree in Sustainable Development at the School of International Training. With her education, determination, and passion work, Sandra blazed a trail as an advocate and humanitarian, often in areas where women were not seen as leaders. Early in her career, she worked as a Senior Associate Director of Peace and Development for the prestigious Jimmy Carter Center. Here she dedicated her work to advancing global peace programs, conflict resolution, democratization, and human rights. Her areas of oversight included Latin America, Africa, and the Middle East. In this role she had a significant impact on critical issues including disease prevention, conflict resolution and the promotion of democracy. Next, she moved to Ma‚Äôan Development Center, a groundbreaking organization committed to fostering social and economic development in underserved communities. As Program Director, she played an instrumental role in designing and implementing innovative programs to tackle poverty, inequality and educational disparities through self-sufficiency and self-empowerment. In her tenure as Director of Program Development and Quality with Save the Children, Sandra harnessed her unwavering advocacy and creativity to address critical issues facing young people including access to educational, health-related and protective resources. When Sandra joined the American Near East Refugee Aid or ANEERA, she was the first woman and first Palestinian to join the organization. In the capacity of Country Director in Palestine, she worked to advance the wellbeing of refugees, families, and communities in Palestine, Jordan and Lebanon. She built partnerships and responded to economic, health, and educational needs through sustainable solutions. It is for her unwavering and visionary commitment to humanitarian causes across the globe, her exceptional contributions to humankind and the shining example of what Sunnyside High School hopes our graduates can accomplish, that we induct Sandra Rasheed into the Sunnyside High School Alumni Wall of Fame. Sandra‚Äôs brother Rashed accepted the award on her behalf.

Asura is a creature born in Makai, the demon world. He's in constant conflict with Yuga, the Destroyer, for being against his plans of unification between the human world and the makai. After losing a battle, Asura ends up being imprisoned. In Samurai Shodown 64, Haohmaru manages to destroy Yuga's physical body, and with that Asura is freed. However, a year later, Yuga manages to revive and creates a clone of Asura, named Shadow Asura, to serve as his subordinate. Shadow Asura is sent on a mission to retrieve Shiki, but ends up falling in love with her and the two have a daughter, Mikoto. Asura and his clone end up joining forces to defeat Yuga once and for all, but at the last moment, Yuga tries to possess Mikoto. Asura and Shadow Asura merge into a single being, and manage to totally destroy Yuga's spirit, thus preventing the girl's body from being controlled by him. However, Mikoto still remains with a certain evil energy that she cannot get rid of. Asura fights with seven different weapons, being a dangerous opponent both at long and close range. His attacks however are not very fast, this being his only weakness. SOUTH AFRICA'S PRESIDENT PLEDGES PALESTINIAN SOLIDARITY On 14 October, South African President Cyril Ramaphosa lambasted the Israeli government's orders for over one million people in Gaza to move south in preparation for a ground invasion, describing it as a genocide in the making. While standing in the South African province of Gauteng, Ramaphosa also expressed his support for the Palestinian people and conveyed his country's willingness to contribute to the resolution of the Israel-Palestine conflict based on a two-state solution. It echoes a recent joint communiqu√© by the African Union and Arab League. Following an incursion by Palestinians into occupied Palestinian territories on 7 October, Israel has responded disproportionately. It has dropped more than 6,000 bombs into the densely packed Gaza Strip, killing thousands, mostly women and children. Hospitals have been overwhelmed, with key medical supplies exhausted. In what has received widespread condemnation for being collective punishment‚Äîa war crime‚ÄîIsrael shut down water, food and electricity supply to Gaza. South Africa‚Äôs stance on Palestine is continuation of a long-running tradition of solidarity. South Africa credits international solidarity for playing a part in the defeat of apartheid, a situation Palestine finds itself in today, according to multiple human rights organizations. Palestinians are discriminated against on their own land, heavily surveilled and are denied freedom of movement. Israel is building settlements on existing Palestinian villages, and has ignored countless international calls to respect Palestinian rights. South Africa is one of a growing number of countries putting out international calls for a just conclusion to the Palestinian question. Other states include Egypt and Algeria in Africa, as well as Iran and Saudi Arabia, which might just have to press pause on normalisation of ties with Israel. Let us know what you think about Ramaphosa's remarks. #CyrilRamaphosa #SouthAfrica #Israel #Gaza #Invasion #Genocide #AU #Palestine

QUESTION :Whats the reason that Nyoka Longa is the one that remained out of anyone else. He doesnt strike me as the most talented at the time when there was evoloko and papa wemba. What made it that he stood the test of time and became the face of Zaiko? Was he already somewhat the face of Zaiko back then? Is he musically inclided and knows how to play a few instruments? What is it about the guy. ANSWER üåü Zaiko was founded because of Papa Wemba's voice with Pedro Felix Manuaku (who came from the previous called Belguide which was disbanded by the founders of Zaiko after discovering Papa Wemba) and Papa Wemba(then called Jules Presley) being the first musicians with the rest being recruited some days later. Zaiko was founded by D.V. Moanda, Marcelin Delo, Henry Mongombe, Andre Bita and Olemi Eshar-Eshar. Back in the days band were mostly founded and directed by donors. Alot those bands used then to have two bands. One band which was playing American-music (Pop, Soul, R&B) and the other band typical Congolese music. Zaiko was one of those bands until 1988. For people who don't know it, the first star of Zaiko was Nyoka Longo with his song La Blanche Neige which was a hit in 1970. But Zaiko was then not really a big band they used to copy Los Nickelos, which was a band of Congolese students based in Belgium. They feared Thu Zahina who were beside of Tabu Ley and Los Nickelos their rolmodels and the reference the young generation until Verckys Kiamangana and Franco Luambo killed the band in 1972 by signing the band to their label but not producing them and recruiting their best musicians. In 1971 Gina Efonge joined the band and the band changed immediatly. Zaiko started to become famous with his songs and he became then the star of the band. The same year the created the Cavacha-rhythm which all drummers of took over and is played until this day. Not long after that they created inside the band a platform called Isifi (Institut du Savoir Ideologique pour la Formation des Idoles) which had Gina Efonge, Evoloko Lay, Papa Wemba, Mavuela Somo and some other musicians, excluding Nyoka Longo. Because in Gina's eyes he was a "yuma" and he couldn't join them, because he came from Masina. Nyoka Longo was then mostly not singing in their songs and concerts and started then to focus on the administration of Zaiko. In 1973 Zaiko was the most popular band of Zaire and Evoloko became then the face of the band with his hits Mbeya Mbeya and Eluzam. In 1973 Gina Efonge lost his head and was replaced by Bozi Boziana. In at the end of 1974, Evoloko Lay, Papa Wemba, Mavuela Somo and Bozi Boziana decided to leave Zaiko and to form Isifi Lokole with Zaiko only being left with the instrumentists and the singers Nyoka Longo and Bimi Ombale who returned in 1973 as singer (he used to be a drummer), but was like Nyoka Longo excluded. They recruited musicians and went back to the Los Nickelos-style. They formed a dangerous singing-group (Likinga Redo, Nyoka Longo, Lengi Lenga, Bimi Ombale) called Le Quartet joined by showman Mbuta Mashakado who used to be the choreographer of Evoloko and a pop-singer in Zaiko before the split. Mbuta Mashako, Nyoka Longo and Bimi were then the start of the band. Then in 1976, Gina Efonge recovered and rejoined Zaiko. In 1977 Bozi Boziana also rejoined Zaiko and it made the band stronger, the same year Gina left to form his own band Libanko after getting his fame back. In 1978 Evoloko rejoined Zaiko and from then they started to fight against Viva La Musica about being the most popular band. But Nyoka Longo didn't like him, because he felt like Evoloko came to steal his rol as being the top-star of the band, which often resulted in conflicts. Then in 1979 Manuaku Waku became the star of the band with his hits Obi and Femme n'est Pleur Pas. The same year just before celebrating Zaiko's 10th Anniversary, Nyoka Longo and his friends fired Manuaku Waku from the band with Evoloko Lay, Bozi Boziana, Djudju-chet and many others who were making part of Zaiko. Zaiko used then to have more then 30 musicians and it was easy to split the band in 3 with them performing on three different places in Kinshasa. Manuaku then decided to start Grand Zaiko Wawa with the rest, but then Franco decided to reconcile them and they all rejoined. But the conflict between Nyoka Longo and Manuaku was so big that, Manuaku decided to leave and start his own band. The departure of Manuaku made that nobody could protect Evoloko from Nyoka Longo which made Evoloko singing barely in concerts (sometimes only 2 songs). Because Manuaku used to be the chef d'orchestre of Zaiko. So Evoloko decided to contact Verckys Kiamuangana to form his own band with Evoloko then contacting his best friend Bozi, Djo Mali and other musicians of Zaiko to form Langa Langa Stars in 1981. The split fragilized Zaiko, but they continued. Then Nyoka Longo discovered that Verckys slept with his wife which made him furious and he decided to sing the song (truncated)

A landlord has been charged with murder and hate crimes after allegedly stabbing a Palestinian American six-year-old boy to death and seriously wounding his mother.

Joseph Czuba, 71, allegedly attacked his tenants in their home in Plainfield Township, about 40 miles (64 km) southwest of Chicago, because of the conflict between Hamas and Israel. He has been charged with first-degree murder, attempted first-degree murder, two counts of hate crime and aggravated battery with a deadly weapon.

‚ÄúDetectives were able to determine that both victims in this brutal attack were targeted by the suspect due to them being Muslim and the ongoing Middle Eastern conflict involving Hamas and the Israelis,‚Äù the Will County sheriff‚Äôs office said in a statement.

Police said that the boy, Wadea Al-Fayoume, was stabbed 26 times with a military-style knife, and later died in hospital. His mother, named as Hanaan Shahin, was also stabbed more than a dozen times, seriously injuring her, but she is expected to survive.

President Joe Biden said he was "sickened" by Saturday's attack on a family who had come to America ‚Äúseeking what we all seek ‚Äì a refuge to live, learn, and pray in peace."

‚ÄúThis horrific act of hate has no place in America, and stands against our fundamental values: freedom from fear for how we pray, what we believe, and who we are,‚Äù he said.

Two-thirds of Americans say the United States should publicly support Israel in the war between Israel and Hamas, according to the latest NPR/PBS NewsHour/Marist poll, but there are wide generational and racial divides on the question.‚Å†
‚Å†
At this point, more Americans, but not a majority, think Israel's response has been appropriate, though an overwhelming number of respondents are worried the war will spill over into a broader regional conflict.‚Å†
‚Å†
Seven in 10 Americans said they are paying close attention to the war. And, even though most agree that the U.S. should publicly support Israel, President Biden ‚Äî who has voiced strong public support for the Jewish nation ‚Äî is not benefiting politically.‚Å†
‚Å†

People all over the world gathered this past weekend to protest Israel's attack on the Gaza Strip. Demonstrations were seen in the U.S., Algeria, Australia, and the Middle East, among others. Many had signs with information about the conflict and a call to end the attacks.

The protests come after a week's worth of Israeli airstrikes on Gaza. More than 2,000 Palestinian civilians have been killed and more than 9,000 have been injured since October 7, while Israeli authorities say 1,400 of its population have died and 3,400 have been injured in the war. Currently people in Gaza have limited access to food, water, and electricity.

The Latin Catholic patriarch of Jerusalem has offered to be exchanged for the children being held hostage in the Gaza Strip by Hamas. 

Speaking to journalists via video conference on Oct.16, Cardinal Pierbattista Pizzaballa was asked if he would be willing to offer himself in exchange to free the children hostages who were taken in Hamas‚Äô attack on Israel last week. The cardinal responded that he is willing to do anything to ‚Äúbring those children home.‚Äù 

‚ÄúAm I ready for an exchange? Anything, if that can lead to freedom and bring those children home, no problem. There is an absolute availability on my part,‚Äù the cardinal said.

Israel Defense Forces announced Monday that 199 Israeli hostages, including children, are being held by Hamas and that the military is trying to understand where they are being held in Gaza. Hamas terrorists had threatened last week to kill one hostage every time that Israel‚Äôs military bombs civilian targets in Gaza.

The cardinal underlined that it is necessary ‚Äúto find a way to get the hostages back.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe are willing to help, even me personally,‚Äù he added. 

Pizzaballa, who serves as the head of Latin Catholics living in Israel, the Palestinian territories, Jordan, and Cyprus, noted that he had not had any direct communication with Hamas since the surprise attack on Israel on Oct. 7. 

The Vatican is willing to help mediate a peace agreement, according to Vatican Secretary of State Cardinal Pietro Parolin, who said in an interview Friday that the Vatican‚Äôs chief concern amid the conflict is ‚Äúthe release of Israeli hostages and the protection of innocent lives in Gaza.‚Äù 

‚ÄúI do not know how much room for dialogue there can be between Israel and the Hamas militia,‚Äù Parolin said. ‚ÄúBut if there is ‚Äî and we hope there is ‚Äî it should be pursued immediately and without delay.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Holy See is ready for any necessary mediation, as always,‚Äù he said.

Pizzaballa has called for a day of prayer and fasting for peace and reconciliation in the Holy Land on Tuesday, Oct. 17, urging Catholics to organize times of prayer with Eucharistic adoration and recitation of the rosary.

Full story at link in bio.

#catholic #prayers

On Saturday, a protestor interrupted President Joe Biden‚Äôs speech at a national LGBTQ+ organization‚Äôs gala to call for a ceasefire in Gaza.

Biden spoke at the Human Rights Campaign‚Äôs National Dinner this weekend, where he gave a speech surveying the state of LGBTQ+ rights across America, including promises from his administration to continue fighting for LGBTQ+ equality at home and abroad. He had just started speaking, however, when an audience member stood and repeatedly yelled, ‚ÄúLet Gaza live! Ceasefire now!‚Äù

Biden responded that he couldn‚Äôt hear what the protestor was saying and replied, ‚ÄúWhatever you‚Äôre saying, I‚Äôm going to say thank ‚Äî I can‚Äôt hear you.‚Äù

Later in the speech, he referenced the ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas, acknowledging both the Israeli ‚Äúchildren and grandparents‚Ä¶ kidnapped and held hostage by Hamas‚Äù and the ‚Äúhumanitarian crisis in Gaza.‚Äù Read more at the link in bio.

We must win this war of souls. In its war against Hamas, Israel has a duty to defend its territory and its citizens, but it must also defend its humanity. Our war is with Hamas, not with the Palestinian people. Palestinian civilians deserve to enjoy peace and prosperity in their homeland, and even in the midst of conflict their basic human rights should be recognized by all sides. This refers not only to Israel, but also to Egypt, which shares a border with the Gaza Strip, and which has partially sealed that border. Right now, the minds of both Israelis and Palestinians are filled to the brim with their own pain: no space is left to even acknowledge the pain of the other side. But outsiders who are not themselves immersed in pain should make an effort to empathize with all suffering humans, rather than lazily seeing only part of the terrible reality. It is the job of outsiders to help maintain a space for peace.

This very common issue can be really confusing for both parties involved‚Ä¶

When one partner perceives another partner‚Äôs expression of needs, wants, and feedback as being critical, controlling, or ungrateful‚Ä¶ this creates a dilemma of a repeated trigger cycle‚Ä¶

Because Partner A is being triggered when their needs are dismissed and neglected and Partner B is triggered because they feel criticized and controlled by Partner A‚Äôs expression of needs, hurts, or feedback‚Ä¶ 

Thus, both partners are constantly being triggered and neither partner is consistently getting their needs met‚Ä¶ 

And round and round it goes. 

The most difficult part of these dynamics is that each partner is inevitably caught up in their Relationship Programming‚Ä¶ experiencing a perpetuation of their trauma and negative core beliefs, but because it‚Äôs familiar, they keep doing this dance on loop‚Ä¶ because well, it‚Äôs what they know.

If you recognize you‚Äôre in a dynamic where you are not ‚Äúallowed‚Äù to express needs, hurts, feedback, etc. without it leading to conflict or worse‚Ä¶ You might want to assess if this relationship is a reflection of your programming‚Ä¶ as well as a reflection of your partner‚Äôs programming. 

And, if so, it might be time to re-evaluate‚Ä¶ ‚ô•Ô∏è

In a tragic incident that has shocked the community, an Illinois landlord has been arrested and charged with a hate crime after allegedly stabbing a 6-year-old Muslim boy to death and seriously injuring his mother. The man reportedly targeted the victims based on their faith and as a response to the ongoing Israel-Hamas war.
__________________________________________________
According to the Associated Press, a woman identified as Hanaan Shahin, had called 911 to report that her landlord had attacked her and her child with a knife. She told the operator that she ran into a bathroom and continued to fight him off. While arriving at the scene, officers found the 32-year-old wounded woman and little boy late Saturday morning at the home located in an unincorporated area of Plainfield Township. The man suspected, 71-year-old Joseph Czuba, was found outside the residence ‚Äúsitting upright on the ground near the driveway of the residence‚Äù with cuts on his face. From there he was immediately taken into police custody. 
__________________________________________________
The innocent little boy, Wadea Al-Fayoume, was taken to a local hospital where he was pronounced dead.  The woman was seen for multiple stab wounds but is expected to survive, according to a statement. The autopsy revealed that the child had been stabbed a total of 26 times. The sheriff‚Äôs department said in a statement, ‚ÄúDetectives were able to determine that both victims in this brutal attack were targeted by the suspect due to them being Muslim and the ongoing Middle Eastern conflict involving Hamas and the Israelis.‚Äù

71-year-old Joseph Czuba‚Äîtheir landlord‚Äîwas charged with first-degree murder, attempted first-degree murder, two counts of hate crimes, and aggravated battery with a deadly weapon. In texts to her son‚Äôs father, Shahin recalled the landlord's words: ‚ÄòYou Muslims must die.‚Äô

Wadea was laid to rest today.

The Latin Catholic patriarch of Jerusalem has offered to be exchanged for the children being held hostage in the Gaza Strip by Hamas. 

Speaking to journalists via video conference on Oct.16, Cardinal Pierbattista Pizzaballa was asked if he would be willing to offer himself in exchange to free the children hostages who were taken in Hamas‚Äô attack on Israel last week. The cardinal responded that he is willing to do anything to ‚Äúbring those children home.‚Äù 

‚ÄúAm I ready for an exchange? Anything, if that can lead to freedom and bring those children home, no problem. There is an absolute availability on my part,‚Äù the cardinal said.

Israel Defense Forces announced Monday that 199 Israeli hostages, including children, are being held by Hamas and that the military is trying to understand where they are being held in Gaza. Hamas terrorists had threatened last week to kill one hostage every time that Israel‚Äôs military bombs civilian targets in Gaza.

The cardinal underlined that it is necessary ‚Äúto find a way to get the hostages back.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe are willing to help, even me personally,‚Äù he added. 

Pizzaballa, who serves as the head of Latin Catholics living in Israel, the Palestinian territories, Jordan, and Cyprus, noted that he had not had any direct communication with Hamas since the surprise attack on Israel on Oct. 7. 

The Vatican is willing to help mediate a peace agreement, according to Vatican Secretary of State Cardinal Pietro Parolin, who said in an interview Friday that the Vatican‚Äôs chief concern amid the conflict is ‚Äúthe release of Israeli hostages and the protection of innocent lives in Gaza.‚Äù 

‚ÄúI do not know how much room for dialogue there can be between Israel and the Hamas militia,‚Äù Parolin said. ‚ÄúBut if there is ‚Äî and we hope there is ‚Äî it should be pursued immediately and without delay.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Holy See is ready for any necessary mediation, as always,‚Äù he said.

Pizzaballa has called for a day of prayer and fasting for peace and reconciliation in the Holy Land on Tuesday, Oct. 17, urging Catholics to organize times of prayer with Eucharistic adoration and recitation of the rosary.

Full story at link in bio.

The 4 core needs of our nervous system:
‚Äã
1. SAFETY means that the nervous system feels secure, protected, resourced and able to regulate the intensity of emotional, physiological, psychological and relational responses. Safety is about having a stable somatic foundation from which to engage with the world.
‚Äã
When this need is not sufficiently met (embodied), the nervous system adapts through survival strategies/roles to substitute for the lack of safety. Survival means seeking safety in adaptive ways. 
‚Äã
When this dynamic becomes ongoing, we experience an internal conflict between 2 opposing needs: the need for safety (still unmet) and the momentum to seek safety in survival ways because that's what the system did for so long. 
‚Äã
2. CONNECTION: Humans are social beings, and our nervous system has a profound need for connection. This goes beyond human connection; The nervous system is an interconnected system. It needs to feel itself as part of Nature. 
‚Äã
When this need is not met or insufficiently met, the nervous system will perceive the relational field (internal, external) as unsafe and adapt through isolation from Nature or codependency, for example. 
‚Äã
3. ACTIVATION (To Be Safely Mobilized). Mobilization of energy, stimulation, excitement, curiosity, play. 
‚Äã
4. REST (To Be Safely Deactivated). Relaxation, rejuvenation, rest, sleep, integration
‚Äã
Activation/Deactivation is the core cycle through which our nervous system regulates our inner life. When this cycle is disrupted, the nervous system engages more energy in self-protection.

Healing means the path of restoring and embodying these 4 core needs. 
‚Äã
Inside the book Embodied Healing, I offer many trauma and nervous system-informed frameworks and insights to address these 4 needs and build a sustainable healing momentum. Link in bio to get your copy.
‚Äã
Love,
Ally. ‚Äã

At least 30% of conflict between partners comes from misunderstandings. We think we‚Äôre getting a message we‚Äôre not getting (often it‚Äôs ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt care about you‚Äù) which can be more related to past experiences than it is the reality of the moment, and then we react to what we‚Äôve created in our mind, leaving our partner feeling misunderstood and triggered. Your reasons for misunderstanding makes sense. Misunderstandings aren‚Äôt random. They‚Äôre related to real events from the past (childhood, former relationships, or events in you current relationship) that have given you good reason to jump to conclusions. Our brains are wired to jump to conclusions for the sake of efficiency and staying safe. At the same time, partners who are trying to do better and grow can get boxed in by misunderstandings, and everyone feels demoralized and stuck. What‚Äôs the solution? Curiosity. Before reacting, try to step back and say ‚Äúhey, I think we might be missing each other. What are you trying to say to me right now?‚Äù

That aid has been delivered to the south, central and north parts of Israel. We now have over 400 pallets of aid in transit to Israel. We have warehouses set up in Tel Aviv already.
