Reportedly, the celebrity dad stated when asked about the topic:

‚ÄúIf you say something about this one you‚Äôre going to get criticized, right, and if you say something about someone else you‚Äôre going to get [criticized]‚Ä¶So stay out of it, you know, like especially if you‚Äôre somebody that‚Äôs well known.‚Äù

Adding:

‚ÄúBeing a celebrity and [saying] something favoring one against the other and it‚Äôs going to come back on you,‚Äù

Dennis Graham‚Äôs comments come days after culture commentator #DJVlad called out Drake and #DJKhaled for failing to use their platforms to speak on the war. In case you‚Äôre unfamiliar, an alleged terrorist group called the Hamas reportedly launched a missile attack on the citizens of Israel last week, sparking a full on war on the Gaza strip between the #Israelis and #Palestines. As we covered, pop star #BrunoMars had to cancel two appearances in the Middle East due to having to immediately evacuate because of the conflict.

The situation has caused many celebrities to speak for or against one side or the other, which is why DJ Vlad took issue with the silence of Drake, who is of Jewish decent, and DJ Khaled, who is of Palestinian descent. 

He wrote on X (formerly Twitter):

‚ÄúHas anyone noticed that the most famous Jewish person on Earth, Drake, and the most famous Palestinian person on Earth, DJ Khaled, haven‚Äôt said a single thing about the Gaza-Israel conflict? It‚Äôs not like Drake is too busy. He‚Äôs been writing paragraphs about Joe Budden hurting his feelings about his new album. DJ Khaled has been working overtime promoting his new Jordan sneakers. In the midst of the ongoing ethnic conflict between Meiteis and Kukis, disturbing posters have emerged in Moirang town, Manipur, urging Kukis to 'go back to Israel.' This development follows reports that over 200 Kuki fighters, rooted in Manipur and Mizoram, are set to join Israel's Defence Force (IDF) in their fight against Hamas in Palestine.

Of the 3,60,000 reserve soldiers in IDF, 206 belong to the Kuki community, who initially migrated to Israel under the country's open-door policy for 'lost Jewish tribes.' Presently, around 5,000 Kukis reside in Israel, with most living in Sderot, a city near Gaza, facing the brunt of recent violence. The Bnei Menashe, as this community is known in Hebrew, witnessed their homes affected, with one family's house burned. 

In Aizawl, prayer services have been held for those who lost their lives in Israel, expressing pride in their community members fighting for the IDF. Our wounded parts want to hold onto small things and use them as proof that we're not lovable, not good enough, that our partners are out to get us. A big part of learning to be happy in relationship is noticing when our ego wants to indulge in our story of brokenness and choosing to let go instead.

What do I mean by "indulging in a story of brokenness"? When we've been wounded, our ego builds an identity around it.

We may not even realize that we're carrying around stories of being unworthy or unlovable, or that we unconsciously feel drawn to friction, tension, or drama in relationship.

I see Conscious Relationship as the practice of learning to cultivate, harness and carefully direct our energy in a positive direction.

When we're wired to fight, defend, poke and prod or fall into self-pity - it actually takes a lot of energetic practice to let go in the moments where we're feeling activated and have an opportunity to feed the story.

Many of us say we want harmony, but actually we quite enjoy conflict on some level and we're not being honest with ourselves about that.

Maybe what we really enjoy is just the energy - the intensity of feeling or the attention we're receiving. And so we get to ask ourselves - is this how I want to use my energy?

Do I need to respond to the thing my partner just said or did with more fire? Do I want to spend my energy on arguing, being right, proving a point, or can I channel this energy back into my heart and express myself in a way that will create an opportunity to deepen in love?

Choosing peace isn't as simple as saying we want it. Choosing peace is a life-long practice of self-observation, dancing with energy and choosing where to put it.

Taking deep breaths, Seeing our partners heart, Responding with a loving statement rather than being defensive (even when you're annoyed), or simply finding a tree to admire ... are all ways to ground into the present moment and realize that life is too precious to spend wasting our energy away on things that don't matter.

Ramses II, one of ancient Egypt's most illustrious kings, left an indelible mark on history through his reign, which lasted for 66 years, and his impressive accomplishments. Known as Ramses the Great, his legacy remains a testament to the grandeur of the Egyptian civilization.

Ramses II ascended to the throne in 1279 BC, inheriting a kingdom deeply rooted in tradition. Throughout his rule, he sought to not only maintain Egypt's prestige but also expand its borders. One of his most significant achievements was the signing of the first-ever known peace treaty with the Hittites, marking the end of a long-standing conflict.

This era was also marked by extensive construction projects. Perhaps the most famous of these is the grand temple complex of Abu Simbel, carved into the cliffs along the Nile. The colossal statues of Ramses II, standing guard at the entrance, stand as a testament to his might and architectural vision.

Ramses II's reign was marked by prolific building endeavors, including the construction of the iconic Luxor Temple, Karnak Temple, and the Ramesseum. His monuments not only served as a reminder of his power but also as places of worship and veneration for generations to come.

Beyond his military and architectural achievements, Ramses II was a prolific writer, leaving behind a wealth of inscriptions and texts. His military campaigns and diplomatic efforts are meticulously documented, providing invaluable insights into the ancient world.

Even in death, Ramses II's legacy endures. His mummified remains, discovered in the 19th century, continue to be a subject of fascination and scientific study. The intricate preservation of his body, along with the opulent treasures found in his tomb, emphasize the importance he placed on the afterlife.

Ramses the Great's reign was an epoch of grandeur, diplomacy, and construction, forever etching his name into the annals of history. His legacy stands as a symbol of the magnificence of ancient Egypt, inspiring wonder and admiration across the ages.

@SceneNoise: Palestinian Resistance Music Then & Now

In a decades-long oppression that continually affects millions within Palestine and amongst the diaspora of its people, Palestinians have struggled to have their voice heard through traditional media outlets.
Determined to speak out and break the silence, over the years, Arab and Palestinian artists have found a way to discuss the conflict's complexity through music, by voicing their daily struggles, their dreams of a brighter future, and the surreal experiences of living with war and occupation.

In this list, we've compiled songs that take us through the history of Palestinian resistance music, where artists and poets address specific moments of the conflict, dealing with their grief and frustration, and painting a more well-rounded picture of how Palestinians feel about the extraordinary circumstances they have been put through along the years.

To read the full feature, head to scenenoise.com or download the #SceneNOW app for iOS and Android.

Yesterday, The New York Times reported that the Israeli ground invasion, initially scheduled for this weekend, was postponed for a few days due to bad weather. Experts however think Israel's expected all-out ground assault on Gaza has been postponed out of fears it could escalate into a regionwide war. 

After a day of escalating strikes around the Israeli-Lebanese border, which could escalate into a full-scale war with Lebanon-based Hezbollah, there‚Äôs fear the violence will spread to other parts of the region.

And last night, Iran warned Israel once again that if it escalates the conflict in Gaza it risks drawing in the involvement of Iran's military. If Iran enters the Israel-Hamas War, there's a risk Syria will get dragged into the war as well, completely setting ablaze a region that is already one of the most explosive ones in the world. 

Earlier, on Saturday, the Pentagon ordered a second carrier strike group (lead by the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower) to the eastern Mediterranean Sea and is sending Air Force fighter jets to the region as Israel prepares to expand its Gaza operations. The first US Navy carrier strike group (led by the USS Gerald R. Ford) that was sent to the region, arrived off the coast of Israel last week. The US warships are not intended to join the fighting in Gaza or take part in Israel‚Äôs operations, but the presence of two of the US Navy‚Äôs most powerful vessels is designed to send a message of deterrence to Iran and Iranian proxies in the region, such as Hezbollah in Lebanon. 

Meanwhile, US Air Forces Central Command on Saturday announced the deployment of F-15E fighter jets and A-10 ground-attack jets to an air base in Jordan to further bolster the U.S. defense posture in the region as part of the effort to deter hostile actions against Israel or any efforts toward widening this war following Hamas‚Äôs attack on Israel. If deterrence however fails, the U.S. could be forced to enter the war as well.

@SceneNoise: Palestinian Resistance Music Then & Now

In a decades-long oppression that continually affects millions within Palestine and amongst the diaspora of its people, Palestinians have struggled to have their voice heard through traditional media outlets.
Determined to speak out and break the silence, over the years, Arab and Palestinian artists have found a way to discuss the conflict's complexity through music, by voicing their daily struggles, their dreams of a brighter future, and the surreal experiences of living with war and occupation.

In this list, we've compiled songs that take us through the history of Palestinian resistance music, where artists and poets address specific moments of the conflict, dealing with their grief and frustration, and painting a more well-rounded picture of how Palestinians feel about the extraordinary circumstances they have been put through along the years.

To read the full feature, head to scenenoise.com or download the #SceneNOW app for iOS and Android.

Given the ongoing conflict between Palestine and Israel, it is no longer acceptable for me to remain silent. 

It is imperative that we speak out against the injustices taking place in that region. My heart strongly aligns with the plea for peace and justice. 

It is crucial that we support the innocent lives impacted by this conflict. Together, let us magnify the voices that promote peace, unity, and the welfare of all.

A macabre video that spread across social media platforms last week showed a young girl being set on fire by a mob, which sharers claimed was the doing of Hamas. But the footage was, in fact, from 2015 in Guatemala, long before the Palestinian group‚Äôs attack on Israel. ‚Å†
‚Å†
It was just one falsehood during a week in which often violent misinformation flooded social apps, causing confusion and stoking outrage as the conflict unfolded. Platforms such as Elon Musk‚Äôs X, Telegram and TikTok drew the ire of regulators for failing to stop the deluge of misleading information, which quickly spilled into mainstream media and real world politics. ‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄòOnline lies are skyrocketing, leading to intense emotions across multiple time zones, with huge global and social implications. The size and spread is without precedent,‚Äô said Jean-Claude Goldenstein, chief executive of business intelligence group CREOpoint which focuses on disinformation.‚Å†
‚Å†
X, formerly Twitter, now faces an EU investigation into how it is handling illegal content and misinformation. Chinese-owned TikTok and Mark Zuckerberg‚Äôs Meta have received warnings from Brussels.‚Å†
‚Å†
Tap the link in our bio to read the full story.‚Å†
‚Å†

‚Å†

Singapore is deeply distressed by the increasing civilian casualty toll and deepening humanitarian crisis in the Gaza Strip. These arise from Israeli military operations in response to the attacks by Hamas on Israel on 7 October 2023.

Hamas deliberately targeted civilians, murdering and kidnapping them, and perpetrating abhorrent acts of terror. These atrocities cannot be justified by any rationale. We call for the immediate and safe release of all civilians taken hostage by Hamas.

Israel has the legitimate right to defend its citizens and its territory. However, in exercising this right Israel must comply with international law, including the laws of war. It must do its utmost to protect the safety and security of civilians.

We urge all parties to abide by international humanitarian law and allow for the urgent delivery of humanitarian aid to the civilian population in the Gaza Strip. 

In response to the urgent humanitarian situation, the Singapore Government will contribute S$300,000 towards humanitarian relief operations through the Singapore Red Cross. 

Tragically, too many lives on both sides of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict have been lost in repeated cycles of violence over many decades. Singapore has long held the position that the only viable path to a durable, just and comprehensive resolution to the longstanding conflict is a negotiated two-state solution consistent with relevant United Nations Security Council resolutions. It is convinced that this remains the case. It urges both sides to take steps towards this ultimate goal, despite the recent and ongoing hostilities and the difficulty of the task. Israelis and Palestinians alike deserve to live in peace, security and dignity.

The international community is responsible

For decades, Western governments attempted to ‚Äúmanage the conflict‚Äù in Palestine with ‚Äúconcern‚Äù but no accountability. Now, they are giving Israel the green light to commit a massacre.

Iran warned Israel through the United Nations that it will intervene if Israel‚Äôs operation in Gaza continues.

Iran told the UN that it does not want to see Israel‚Äôs conflict with Hamas escalate into a wider regional war, according to diplomatic sources.

Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian met with UN envoy to the Middle East Tor Wennesland on Saturday in Beirut, the two diplomatic sources said. Wennesland urged Amir-Abdollahian to help prevent a spillover of the conflict in Gaza and Israel to the wider region in the Middle East.

The Iranian foreign minister replied that Iran doesn‚Äôt want the conflict to turn into a regional war and wants to try to help with the release of civilians who are being held hostage by Hamas in Gaza.

But Amir-Abdollahian stressed that Iran has its red lines. He said that if the Israeli military operation continues ‚Äî and especially if Israel follows through on its promise of a ground offensive in Gaza ‚Äî Iran will have to respond, according to the sources.

Probably the number one thing I‚Äôm most proud of in my life is my marriage with Cass. We have been so intentional and always willing to put in the hard work to build the foundation for a truly epic love. Now 5+ years together and 2 years married we get to see the fruit of our efforts more and more everyday. ü´∂üèª

Our top 3 tips for building an epic marriage üëáüèª

1) Choose a partner who you trust to be your mirror. Marriage is a lot of feedback, and learning how to put down your own defenses and grow together. I don‚Äôt always like it when Cass points out something I may need to change in myself but ultimately I trust them and have always been better for it ‚ú®

2) Don‚Äôt be afraid to get some third party help. Marriage is SO much communication and blending communication styles. If there are some hurdles you are encountering in blending those styles a couples therapist is an amazing tool. We like to touch base with ours when we aren‚Äôt in conflict so we can build tools to keep it that way üí™üèª

3) wake up and get to know your partner everyday. Cass and I are very growth-centered people and are constantly evolving. We look at each other with fresh eyes and excitement wondering what we will become next üòç

üì∏ @masonphotography

New Delhi: A six-year-old Muslim boy and his 32-year-old mother were attacked with a knife by their 71-year-old landlord in Illinois, US, in a hate crime reportedly triggered by the conflict in Israel and Palestine. The boy, Wadea al-Fayoume, lost his life. His mother, Hanaan Shahin, a Palestinian who moved from the West Bank to the US 12 years ago, has multiple stab wounds and is in the hospital, BBC reported.

The accused, Joseph Czuba, has been charged with first-degree murder, attempted first-degree murder, hate crimes and aggravated battery.

The attack reportedly took place on Saturday (October 14). In a statement on Sunday, the Will County Sheriff‚Äôs Office said they had received an emergency call from Shahin (though the statement did not name her), who said she was being attacked by her landlord in Plainfield, near Chicago.

‚ÄúThe knife used in this attack is a 12-inch (31cm) serrated military style knife that has a seven-inch blade,‚Äù the Sheriff‚Äôs office said.

‚ÄúDetectives were able to determine that both victims in this brutal attack were targeted by the suspect due to them being Muslim and the on-going Middle Eastern conflict involving Hamas and the Israelis,‚Äù the sheriff‚Äôs statement said.

Wadea was reportedly stabbed 26 times. He was declared dead when he was taken to the hospital, AP reported.

Read more at thewire.in

Police in the United States have charged a 71-year-old man 'Joseph Czuba' with murder and hate crime for fatally stabbing a six-year-old boy and seriously wounding his 32-year-old mother, alleging he singled out the victims because of their faith and as a response to the war between Israel and Hamas.

‚ÄúDetectives were able to determine that both victims in this brutal attack were targeted by the suspect due to them being Muslim and the on-going Middle Eastern conflict involving Hamas and the Israelis,‚Äù the Will County Sheriff‚Äôs Office in suburban Chicago said in a statement on Sunday.

‚ÄúDetectives were able to determine that both victims in this brutal attack were targeted by the suspect due to them being Muslim and the on-going Middle Eastern conflict involving Hamas and the Israelis,‚Äù the Will County Sheriff‚Äôs Office in suburban Chicago said in a statement on Sunday.

The boy, who was pronounced dead at the hospital, was stabbed 26 times with a large military-style knife, according to an autopsy on Sunday, the sheriff‚Äôs office said.

The mother had more than a dozen stab wounds on her body. She remained hospitalised on Sunday but was expected to survive.

Allow me a humble recommendation. 
Phyllis Bennis did an excellent and clarifying radio interview today about the present horrific situation in Gaza and Israel, outlining it with clarity, but most importantly, putting it in historical context - the only way to begin to grasp the horror we are witnessing. I highly recommend it to English speaking friends here. The link is on my bio. Bennis is a 72 year old Jewish-American writer and activist, a specialist in Middle Eastern politics and in the UN. She wrote the book pictured here, which I also highly recommend to anyone interested in understanding the history of the conflict - and I think we all should be. There are many books on it of course, and I‚Äôm no scholar; this is simply one that is straight forward. It gave me clarity on the matter back in 2015, and it is very relevant now. She also wrote an important article for The Hill on October 8th, one that sent me back to her work, and that I urge you to read now. 
Misinformation is a key weapon in any war, this situation is no exception. Credible information is key to containing heightened emotions, which are understandable in the face of horror.
 I humbly hope this is useful to some of you, as it was to me, and that perspective can help us all towards peace.

Families of those captured or missing because of Hamas‚Äôs attack on Israel are experiencing the unbearable anguish of being in the middle of the world‚Äôs most complicated hostage crisis in recent memory.

On Monday, the number of publicly known hostages increased to almost 200, up from the 150 that had been spoken of since the beginning of the conflict. Experts say that Hamas has most likely locked them up in a warren of underground tunnels in the Gaza Strip, as the Israeli Air Force bombards the territory and the army prepares to invade.

Complaint filed against Rizwan in India for offering prayer on the field. 

A complaint has been filed by an Indian lawyer with the International Cricket Council against Mohammad Rizwan for offering prayer on the field and¬†dedicating Pakistan‚Äôs victory over Sri Lanka to the people of Gaza,¬†Times Now¬†reported.

Rizwan scored a¬†match-winning century against Sri Lanka, which he dedicated to the people of Gaza in light of the ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict.

Vineet Jindal, an advocate of Supreme Court of India lodged a complaint with the ICC against the Pakistani cricketer.

‚ÄúThis is a complaint about Pakistan Cricket Player, Mohammad Rizwan, who was seen offering namaz on the cricket field during his team‚Äôs opening match of the ongoing ICC Men‚Äôs ODI World Cup 2023 on Friday (October 6) against the Netherlands in Hyderabad,‚Äù the complaint read.

Jindal went on to add that Rizwan offering prayer on the cricket field amid many Indians was symbolic of the intentional depiction of his religion which stands against the spirit of the game.

‚ÄúThis very act of the player raises questions about the spirit of the match and raises a question of the ideology, the player follows while playing the match. The act of displaying his religion by Mohammed Rizwan purposefully depicts his intent to message that he is a Muslim, defeating the spirit of sports,‚Äù he said.

Rizwan¬†was seen offering prayers amid the field while his teammates were waiting for the drinks during the break, he added.

For him, the Pakistani wicket-keeping batter‚Äôs statement in his press conference regarding the dedication of his victory to the people of Gaza further attested to his religious and political ideology.

Hopes for a brief ceasefire in southern Gaza to allow foreign passport holders to leave the besieged Palestinian enclave and aid to be brought in were dashed on Monday, with Israeli bombardments intensifying ahead of an expected ground invasion.

Residents of Gaza said the overnight strikes were the heaviest yet in nine days of conflict. Many houses were flattened and the death toll rose inexorably, they said.
Diplomatic efforts have been underway to get aid into the enclave, which has endured unrelenting Israeli bombing since the October 7 attack on Israel by Hamas militants that killed 1,300 people - the bloodiest single day in the state's 75-year history.

Israel has imposed a full blockade and is preparing a ground invasion to enter Gaza and destroy Hamas, which has continued to fire rockets at Israel since its brief cross-border assault. Israeli troops and tanks are already massed on the border.
Authorities in Gaza said at least 2,750 people had so far been killed by the Israeli strikes, a quarter of them children, and nearly 10,000 wounded. A further 1,000 people were missing and believed to be under rubble.

Which adult attachment style (or mix) likely applies to you?üëá

The attachment between a child and a parent is very important. It leads to the development of an attachment style. Any issues with this bond can lead to a trauma in later years, well into adulthood.

Psychologists believe that the attachment style developed by a child can have an effect when the child grows to be an adult themselves. While mixes of attachment styles are possible and the attachment style can change a bit, it is seen that a non-secure attachment style more often leads to dysfunctional relationships and divorce.

The four adult attachment styles have the same names as the childhood ones, but the effects are a bit different as it focuses on how the person deals with the attachment to their partner. A secure attached person feels balanced in relationships and can communicate their needs. They can feel sad, but when their partner is away they can fend for themselves.

People with anxious attachment styles often derive their self-worth from relationships. They need reassurance and constant attention. However, if a person has an avoidant attachment style they withdraw from their partner, have difficulty with intimate relationships and avoids emotions. Lastly, people with disorganised attachment style experience extreme emotional highs and lows, often suffer from substance abuse and avoid responsibility in relationships.

THEY ALL OUT FOR GAZA EMERGENCY PROTEST

The All Out For Gaza Emergency Protest took place today in downtown Saint Louis. The gathering location was Kiener Plaza, and it attracted several hundred supporters who showed up in full force to stand in solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza.

When VOP asked Jeenin Mahmoud, a supporter why she felt compelled to attend the protest, she replied, "I am Palestinian myself, so it's only right to do so. That's the least I could do since I am not there. Besides the guilt I am feeling, I wanted to be their voice. What the media is showing is nothing compared to what's actually going on. They have cut off water, food, and electricity, trying to prevent us from seeing what's happening and educating people."

Another supporter stated, "The events unfolding in front of our eyes are a humanitarian crisis, a genocide, and a war crime. 53% of Gaza's population consists of children. Israel's actions of cutting off water, food, and electricity are considered war crimes. It's crucial for more people to understand that what is happening in Palestine is not a 'conflict' or a 'war.' It's ethnic cleansing."

When asked about the attendees, we were told that ‚Äúthe majority were Palestinians, but the gathering was diverse. One supporter mentioned, "There were a lot of Palestinians, but also many Muslims from different nationalities! I overheard one girl saying that the entire Muslim student group from Maryville showed up!"

On October 7, Hamas, the Palestinian militant group that governs Gaza, launched a surprise attack on Israel, killing over 1,400 civilians. 

Shortly after, Israel‚Äôs military launched air strikes in retaliation, and in the days since, the Israeli government also cut supplies to Gaza, including food, fuel, water, and electricity. Meanwhile, homes and businesses are running low on fuel. Hospitals are expected to be out of fuel entirely in the next 24 hours, leaving thousands of patients‚Äô lives at risk.

Tensions reached a fever pitch when, later in the week, the Israeli state ordered over 1 million Palestinians in northern Gaza evacuate. The United Nations declared the evacuation order impossible, and warned it would only result in "devastating humanitarian consequences,‚Äù while the World Health Organization called it a ‚Äúdeath sentence.‚Äù

Over 2,700 people have been killed by Israel's bombing of Gaza, with an estimated 1,000 MORE missing under rubble, reports the BBC. This period of conflict is only the most recent in over seven decades of occupation in Palestine, and oppression faced by the Palestinian people.

The UN has said that, due to the ongoing conflict, the Middle East is on ‚Äúon the verge of the abyss,‚Äù and is requesting Israel to allow humanitarian aid into Gaza.

That might feel like a lot to digest. With the news rapidly changing, and social media buzzing, if you‚Äôre feeling lost or would like to learn more, here are a few things you can do, read, and watch to get informed about what‚Äôs happening and how you can help, via @so.informed

At Yale, my thesis for my history degree was on how British news coverage of the so-called Indian Mutiny of 1857 ‚Äî in particular, lurid, detailed tales of how white women and children were brutally violated and murdered, including many claims that a later investigative commission could find no evidence to back up ‚Äî whipped up public fervor, laying the groundwork for the British to forcibly conquer India. This military takeover killed tens of thousands of civilians. In subsequent decades of colonial rule, hundreds of thousands more died as the result of British policies.

Misinformation kills. And today, when any one of us can create or share a claim that goes viral, we *all* bear responsibility for not spreading it ‚Äî and for recognizing it when we see it. This post shares one framework to help you start.

Israel has no interest in widening the current conflict, Defence Minister Yoav Gallant has said.
Gallant was speaking against the background of an exchange of fire across the country‚Äôs northern border with Lebanon.

Speaking to Israeli troops on the edge of the Gaza Strip, Gallant said: ‚ÄúWe do not want any escalation of the situation.‚Äù

Gallant made direct reference to the Iran-backed Hezbollah militia active in southern Lebanon.

‚ÄúIf Hezbollah opts for war, they will pay a very high price,‚Äù he warned.

‚ÄúBut if they restrain themselves, we will respect that and keep the situation as it is,‚Äù he added.

Turning to the expected ground offensive by Israeli troops deployed around the Gaza Strip, Gallant said that Israel had a job to do.

The war in Gaza would be intensive, deadly, and precise, he said, adding: ‚ÄúAnd it will change the situation forever,‚Äù he predicted.

Meanwhile, one week after the start of the latest conflict, the number of dead in the Gaza Strip has risen to 2,450, the Ministry of Health in Gaza said on Sunday.

Around 9,200 others were injured in the territory, which is under the control of Hamas, it said.

This means that the number of reported dead on the Palestinian side in just over a week is already higher than during the Gaza war in 2014, when 2,250 people died in the coastal strip within 50 days.

At that time, 66 Israeli soldiers and five civilians were also killed.

The new conflict is thus also the confrontation with the most deaths since Hamas violently took control of the Gaza Strip in 2007.

Hamas massacred Israeli civilians in border towns and at a music festival on Oct. 7.

It was the worst bloodbath in Israeli history.

So far, more than 1,300 people have died in Israel, including 286 servicemen and women.

Israel responded with massive airstrikes on targets in the densely populated coastal strip.

Cecilia James is a music journalist and loves the meaning of songs and lyrics. When she finds a clue that leads to the muse of one of the most popular and secretive love songs ever made, she begins investigating. ‚Å£
‚Å£
I loved the idea of this story! I especially love how it‚Äôs modeled on the song Hey There Delilah, which every young woman in the world wishes was about her in the mid 2000‚Äôs! While the romance itself didn‚Äôt catch me from the beginning, the forbiddeness and conflict was very well done. Health officials in Gaza are grappling with a grim reality as they run out of space for bodies in the wake of Israeli air strikes. As a result, they are using ice cream trucks as temporary morgues. Gaza has been hit by Israeli air strikes in recent weeks in retaliation for a terrorist attack by Hamas. Hospitals and morgues are struggling to cope with the influx of casualties, and with the hospital morgues limited in capacity, unconventional measures have become necessary. Ice cream trucks are now being used to store the deceased due to the risk associated with moving bodies to hospitals.

"The hospital morgue can only take 10 bodies, so we have brought in ice cream freezers from the ice cream factories in order to store the huge numbers of martyrs," says Dr. Yasser Ali from the Shuhada Al-Aqsa hospital. However, even these additional freezers are insufficient to handle the overwhelming number of casualties, forcing some bodies to be stored in tents. The situation is dire, with a substantial death toll and limited resources to manage it.

This devastating scenario highlights the severity of the ongoing conflict, with both sides suffering heavy losses. The Israeli Air Force has launched thousands of bombings in response to the recent terrorist attacks, and the situation shows no sign of immediate resolution. It's a deeply tragic situation that underscores the human cost of these hostilities and the significant challenges faced by health officials on the ground.

(An edited excerpt from a letter by Dalia Hatuqa, a freelance journalist based in the West Bank)

My morning last Saturday began with a barrage of messages on my phone: Hamas had launched an operation and militants had broken through the fence that had kept Palestinians in Gaza under siege for 16 years.

I sent frantic WhatsApp messages to friends from Gaza who live in the West Bank: My neighbor Ola‚Äôs family fled their home. My friend Tahreer said five of her extended family were killed in Israeli shelling. Her friend Eman learned that her father, mother and brother had all died in an airstrike.

Across the street from my house, a charity had opened its doors overnight to house Gaza-based workers who had been expelled from Israel. As I helped my mother drop off clothes for the men, one stood out: He had just heard that his three children had been killed.

For many Palestinians in the West Bank, watching the scenes unfold has been mind-blowing, on a scale that shocks even those who have lived through decades of conflict. Gaza has been under blockade since 2007, when the Hamas movement took over after winning local elections. The Hamas attack was the first time that anyone had been able to break through the fence that kept Palestinians in the coastal enclave hemmed in.

Some have described the attack by Hamas as ‚Äúunprecedented,‚Äù which it is. Others say it is ‚Äúunprovoked,‚Äù but my Palestinian neighbors would beg to differ. They will tell you that over the last 16 years, Israel transformed the Gaza Strip into a pressure cooker, sealing it off from the outside world and decimating it repeatedly with military operations. The result is a grim wasteland with human development indicators like poverty and unemployment on par with the most desolate countries in the world, imposed by a government ostensibly responsible for their welfare.

Recent years have been marked by killings, home demolitions and displacement of entire communities, as documented by rights groups and U.N. agencies. As the amount of territory Palestinians control has shrunk, Palestinians have felt abandoned.

(Continue reading Dalia‚Äôs account from the West Bank at the link in @politicomag‚Äôs bio.)

Complaint filed against Rizwan in India for offering prayer on the field

A complaint has been filed by an Indian lawyer with the International Cricket Council against Mohammad Rizwan for offering prayer on the field and dedicating Pakistan‚Äôs victory over Sri Lanka to the people of Gaza, Times Now reported.

Rizwan scored a match-winning century against Sri Lanka, which he dedicated to the people of Gaza in light of the ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict.

Vineet Jindal, an advocate of Supreme Court of India lodged a complaint with the ICC against the Pakistani cricketer.

‚ÄúThis is a complaint about Pakistan Cricket Player, Mohammad Rizwan, who was seen offering namaz on the cricket field during his team‚Äôs opening match of the ongoing ICC Men‚Äôs ODI World Cup 2023 on Friday (October 6) against the Netherlands in Hyderabad,‚Äù the complaint read.

Jindal went on to add that Rizwan offering prayer on the cricket field amid many Indians was symbolic of the intentional depiction of his religion which stands against the spirit of the game.

‚ÄúThis very act of the player raises questions about the spirit of the match and raises a question of the ideology, the player follows while playing the match. The act of displaying his religion by Mohammed Rizwan purposefully depicts his intent to message that he is a Muslim, defeating the spirit of sports,‚Äù he said.

Rizwan was seen offering prayers amid the field while his teammates were waiting for the drinks during the break, he added.

For him, the Pakistani wicket-keeping batter‚Äôs statement in his press conference regarding the dedication of his victory to the people of Gaza further attested to his religious and political ideology.

Recently, I‚Äôve had a lot going on in my personal life including the passing of our sweet dog, May. So I‚Äôve avoided addressing the conflict in Gaza. 

Honestly, I didn‚Äôt know what to say because I didn‚Äôt have space for the pain. 

All I can say is that I‚Äôm sitting with my pain and heartbreak‚Ä¶.

Reflecting on how to integrate yoga‚Äôs spiritual teachings with my lived human experience, especially when there is so much suffering in the world. 

For me, a healthy, integrated spiritual life begins with acknowledging my pain, feeling my pain. Letting those emotions exist and move through me. 

Yoga is not an escape from reality, but a deep dive into it. 

It‚Äôs the hardest part of my practice - and maybe the most important. Otherwise I‚Äôm living in a fantasy of denial. 

Then I can work on finding more love and compassion for myself and for you. 

Spiritual bypassing happens when I avoid my negative or painful emotions in the name of spirituality. Or, when I use spiritual concepts like oneness or karma to avoid seeing the suffering of others. 

How do you avoid spiritual bypassing and still care for yourself during difficult times?

[ID: 7 black slides with the white text ‚ÄúYoga is not an escape from reality, but a deep dive into it.  Jivana Heyman‚Äù at the bottom.]

National Assembly Deputy Speaker Gladys Shollei has opined that a fuss should not be made out of the office space conflict between Cabinet Secretaries Moses Kuria and Musalia Mudavadi.

This after the Head of Public Service Felix Koskei said on Sunday that the now expanded Prime CS position, which includes the Foreign and Diaspora Affairs docket, headed by Mudavadi, would be located at the old Treasury building on Harambee Avenue.

Meanwhile, the Public Service, Performance, and Delivery Management docket headed by Kuria would take up the Kenya Railways building off Haile Sellasie Avenue which created a point of contention.

The tiff saw Mudavadi's office disputing Koskei's remarks, inviting President William Ruto to the simmering conflict.

In Shollei's view, the matter should be considered a dead letter and should be dismissed since service delivery from the involved ministries will not be compromised.

"I think this is a non-issue really. I don't think it is something we should take our time discussing it. It's like discussing whether my daughter should sleep in the other room and my son should move to the other one and where my housekeeper should sleep," she said.

"It does not really matter at the end of the day it is the service to Kenyans that really matters. What has to be logically looked at is yet this is quite a significant change."

Shollei, who was appearing on Citizen TV's Daybreak show on Monday, stated that it is also unreasonable to invite President Ruto's input on the minute issue, noting that a resolve can be made between the involved parties.

"That is something internal I think they can be able to sort it out. It is a bit ridiculous to tell the head of state to come and manage who sits where. I think he has more important things to deal with," she said.

Read more on the Citizen Digital website.

What happened: Iran's Foreign Minister, Hossein Amirabdollahian, issued a stern warning to Israel, calling for an immediate halt to its military operations in Gaza. He expressed grave concerns that the ongoing conflict could escalate to involve other parts of the Middle East, particularly if Hezbollah, a Lebanese militant group, becomes engaged. Amirabdollahian emphasized that such an escalation would have severe consequences for Israel.

Details: Hezbollah's readiness was a focal point of Amirabdollahian's warning. He revealed that the group had meticulously considered various scenarios for a potential conflict, underscoring the need for Israel to cease its military operations in Gaza. Israel perceives Hezbollah as a significant and immediate threat, given the group's estimated possession of a substantial arsenal, including rockets, missiles, precision-guided projectiles, battle-hardened fighters, and military drones.

Also: His discussions included meetings with key figures, such as Saleh Arouri, a senior Hamas official in exile, and Ziad Nakhaleh, leader of the Palestinian Islamic Jihad group. Amirabdollahian also met with Hezbollah's leader, Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah, who provided insights into the group's status in Lebanon and its preparedness for potential conflicts.
Amirabdollahian issued a strong warning to those involved in actions against Gaza's civilians, urging an immediate halt to prevent further escalation, emphasizing that time was running out.

Few other regions have a history as complicated as the Middle East.

The area is the center of three religious faiths and has been conquered, contested and ruled by various empires across millennia. 

The PBS NewsHour's John Yang takes a look at the most recent history of conflict and conquest, and of suffering and strife, that has led the region to where it is today. Tap the link in our bio to watch the report.

Palestinian-American boy stabbed to death in Gaza war-related killing in US.

Police in the United States have charged a 71-year-old man with murder and hate crime for fatally stabbing a six-year-old boy and seriously wounding his 32-year-old mother, alleging he singled out the victims because of their faith and as a response to the war between Israel and Hamas.

‚ÄúDetectives were able to determine that both victims in this brutal attack were targeted by the suspect due to them being Muslim and the on-going Middle Eastern conflict involving Hamas and the Israelis,‚Äù the Will County Sheriff‚Äôs Office in suburban Chicago said in a statement on Sunday.

Officers found both victims on Saturday morning at a home roughly 65km (40 miles) southwest of Chicago.

The boy, who was pronounced dead at the hospital, was stabbed 26 times with a large military-style knife, according to an autopsy on Sunday, the sheriff‚Äôs office said.

The mother had more than a dozen stab wounds on her body. She remained hospitalised on Sunday but was expected to survive.

The suspect, whose identity has not been revealed by the authorities, was found on Saturday, ‚Äúsitting upright outside on the ground near the driveway of the residence‚Äù with a cut on his forehead, police said.

He was in custody on Sunday and awaiting a court appearance. Police charged him with first-degree murder, attempted first-degree murder, two counts of hate crimes and aggravated battery with a deadly weapon.

‚ÄúOur hearts are heavy, and our prayers are with the darling boy and his mother,‚Äù Ahmed Rehab, the executive director of the Council of American Islamic Relations (CAIR) for the Chicago chapter, said in a statement on their website.

Two wild elephants, aged between 20-25 and 30-35 years, have been electrocuted in a tragic incident in the Tai Rom Yen National Park in Thailand.

Local authorities were alerted by residents who discovered the lifeless bodies of the elephants on October 12.

The initial assessment suggests that the first elephant was electrocuted when they came into contact with the wire and fell to the ground, while the second elephant perished while trying to assist their companion.

The source of the electrocution was an electric fence set up by a durian orchard farmer, raising concerns about human-wildlife conflict in the region.

WFFT is working to protect Thailand‚Äôs wildlife and currently offers sanctuary to 24 rescued elephants. Learn more at wfft.org 

Source: Bangkok Post

This book presents a promising premise with the potential for a gripping legal thriller but falls short of delivering on its potential. 

The protagonist, Jay Singh, is depicted as the archetypal "brilliant but troubled" lawyer with a mysterious past. This character trope is overused in legal thrillers and lacks the freshness and originality needed to engage the reader.

Jay's unwavering commitment to winning cases, even at the cost of bending ethical boundaries, lacks a compelling backstory. His motivation to keep his dark past hidden and the need for redemption isn't developed sufficiently, making it hard to empathize with his character.

The story unfolds in a manner that feels formulaic and predictable. The high-stakes murder case that Jay takes on, while initially intriguing, follows a well-worn path in legal thrillers, with little to distinguish it from similar narratives.

For a legal thriller, the novel often fails to capture the intricacies and nuances of the legal world. Jay's ability to secure victories with unconventional methods stretches believability and detracts from the story's authenticity.

The pacing of the novel is uneven, with slow stretches that may test the reader's patience. While suspense is essential in this genre, the pacing issues disrupt the flow of the narrative and can lead to disengagement.

The novel hints at moral dilemmas faced by Jay as a defense lawyer, but it doesn't dive deep into these ethical challenges. A more profound exploration of the conflict between defending one's reputation and seeking justice would have added depth to the narrative.

Despite the overall entertainment factor, there may be moments when the plot appears a bit too character-centric, potentially overshadowing other important elements of the story.

In conclusion, it struggles to distinguish itself in the crowded legal thriller genre. It's hampered by predictable plot developments, underdeveloped characters, and a lack of legal realism. While the book starts with potential, it ultimately fails to deliver a truly engaging and thought-provoking legal thriller experience.

After witnessing an all-time high mark multiple times last month, India's stock market indices Sensex and Nifty have been facing a rocky road this month amid the Israel-Hamas war. 

Amid the uncertain geopolitical and economic environment across the globe, Indian stocks are witnessing heavy selling from foreign investors.

Sensex is up nearly 0.7% this month, currently hovering around the 66,300 mark, whereas Nifty50 too is up nearly 0.7%, currently hovering around the 19,770 mark. Both Nifty50 and Sensex have jumped nearly 8.5% this year to date, with Sensex being up by more than 5,000 points and Nifty50 being up more 1,500 points. India's stock market indices had outperformed most of the world's major ones last year, click here to know more.

Both Sensex and Nifty had hit their all-time highs of 67,927 and 20,222 respectively in September.

Foreign investors have pulled out nearly Rs 9,800 crore from Indian equities this month so far. This came after Foreign Portfolio Investors (FPIs) turned net sellers in September and pulled out Rs 14,767 crore. On the other hand, FPIs invested Rs 4,000 crore in the country's debt market during the period under review. With this, the total investment by FPIs in equity has reached Rs 1.1 trillion and over Rs 33,000 crore in the debt market this year so far.

In terms of sectors, FPIs continued to sell in financials, power, and IT, however, they continued to buy capital goods and automobiles.

Foreign investors selling Indian stocks heavily this month can be owed to a sustained rise in US bond yields and the uncertain environment resulting from the Israel-Hamas war. 

Going ahead, the trajectory of foreign investors' investments in India will be influenced not only by global inflation and interest rate dynamics but also by the developments and intensity of the Israel-Hamas conflict, Himanshu Srivastava, Associate Director - Manager Research, Morningstar Investment Adviser India, said.

The mother has been in the U.S. for 12 years, and the boy was born in the United States. He celebrated his 6th birthday Oct. 6. Ahmed Rehab, executive director of the Chicago chapter of the Council on American-Islamic Relations, said the boy loved basketball, soccer and ‚Äúanything with a ball.‚Äù Rehab said the suspect had built a treehouse for the child, and the family had no previous problems with him.

Bolingbrook resident Wally Harazin, who drove his family to Plainfield to show solidarity with fellow Muslims, viewed the attack as personal; he has relatives in Gaza. ‚ÄúHow can I protect my kids? How can every Muslim in this country, that we call free, how can they protect their kids. Is this the last hate crime that is going to be against Muslims? I do not think so,‚Äù Harazin said.

We mourn the loss of Martti Ahtisaari, #NobelPeacePrize laureate 2008.

The former Finnish President was awarded the prize for his important efforts, on several continents and over more than three decades, to resolve international conflicts.

Ahtisaari was a major contributor when Namibia achieved independence in 1989-90, arbitrated in Kosovo in 1999 and 2005-07, and helped to bring the long-lasting conflict in the Aceh province in Indonesia to an end in 2005.

‚ÄúThrough his untiring efforts and good results, he has shown what role mediation of various kinds can play in the resolution of international conflicts. The Norwegian Nobel Committee wishes to express the hope that others may be inspired by his efforts and his achievements‚Äù the Norwegian Nobel Committee stated in the announcement in October 2008.

Martti Ahtisaari believed that all conflicts can be revolved, and that peace is a question of will:

‚ÄúWars and conflicts are not inevitable. They are caused by human beings. There are always interests that are furthered by war. Therefore those who have power and influence can also stop them.‚Äù (Nobel Lecture, 2008)

Photo 1: Ken Opprann / The Nobel Foundation
Photo 2: Cornelius Poppe / Nobel Peace Center
Photo 3: Dinamo Story

Do you ever feel like having a baby changed your relationship completely‚Äìand not in a good way? 
 
You‚Äôre not alone. It‚Äôs common for couples to face more conflict and dissatisfaction after a baby is born. 
 
In fact, 67% of couples report a decline in their relationship satisfaction during the first three years of their baby‚Äôs life.* 
 
There are many reasons why new parents often become unhappy with each other. 
 
„Ä∞ Both partners are transitioning into their new roles, which can be difficult. 
„Ä∞ They're sleep-deprived, making them both more irritable and less able to navigate conflict. 
„Ä∞ They are often overstimulated and overwhelmed with new parental responsibilities. 
„Ä∞ They might not see eye-to-eye on parenting decisions or how to adapt to life with a child. 
„Ä∞ Having children comes with new responsibilities and mental labor. 
 
It‚Äôs no wonder so many new parents are struggling! To top it off, the invisible load keeps us so bogged down and overwhelmed, it‚Äôs hard to know where to begin or how to steer our relationship back on track. 
 
This week on The Momwell Podcast, I‚Äôm joined by Aaron Steinberg, MA, co-founder of @thegrowtogetherco. We discuss the toll having a baby can take on a relationship and what you and your partner can do to get back on the same team. 
 
The good news is that we CAN learn how to work through conflict and navigate these relationship changes. We don‚Äôt have to wait until our children are older to reconnect and find satisfaction in our relationships again. 
 
If you‚Äôre feeling distant from your partner and crave the closeness you once felt, our Reconnect Bundle might be for you! 
 
You‚Äôll learn how to: 
 
‚úîÔ∏é Get on the same page 
‚úîÔ∏é Share the load of parenthood 
‚úîÔ∏é Better communicate with one another 
‚úîÔ∏é Grow closer in intimacy 
‚úîÔ∏é And build a meaningful bond 
 
Head to momwell.com/reconnect or click the link in bio to learn more!

Let‚Äôs hear it for‚Ä¶ KAY SIBAL! Kay is our Assistant Musical Director as well as an understudy for various roles. Read below to learn more about Kay! 

TICKETS: tinyurl.com/ewpawakening

Q: What‚Äôs your favorite song to perform?
A: Touch Me is my favorite song not only because Preston did an unimaginably gorgeous job with the choreography, but because the dance moves themselves feel cathartic and soothing to perform! It's a beautiful representation of the unity of the cast and a celebration of self expression <3

Q: What makes THIS Spring Awakening so important to watch?
A: This cast represents what our future will look like: strong-willed young humans of color who long to heal the scars of the past. So many issues of our world are soon to be left in the hands of the next generation--issues of the environment, society, physical and mental health, etc. As a cast of color with many immigrant parents, and experiences with intergenerational conflict, we found that we are especially passionate about these issues. We're determined to take charge of the future, discontinue toxic patterns, and find solutions. That determination is what fuels the fire of our Spring Awakening, and that is why it is so important to watch.

Q: What is your favorite line in the show?
A: I love what Ilse sings in her solo at the very end of the show -"Listen to what's in the heart of a child, a song so big in one so small." It captures the precious idea that I mentioned before -children are the future leaders of the world, and should be listened to. Adults are understandably so complicated, and there is so much simplicity and truth that can be learned from a child. 

Q: Does your role as AMD help you learn all the tracks you understudy?
A: It absolutely does! While making rehearsal tracks for the cast, I had the opportunity to tune into each part early on in the process. As AMD I listen to the songs from an overall arrangement standpoint to make sure balance, harmony, and blend is okay, which forces me to be familiar with multiple parts at a time. But it should be known that this cast is so talented that they learned their parts instantaneously, and that they help me more than I help them :))

Man killed Muslim boy and wounded woman in hate crime motivated by Israeli-Hamas war, police say

A 71-year-old Illinois man accused of fatally stabbing a 6-year-old boy and seriously wounding a 32-year-old woman was charged with a hate crime Sunday. Police allege he singled out the victims because of their Islamic faith and as a response to the war between Israel and Hamas.

Officers found the woman and boy late Saturday morning at a home in an unincorporated area of Plainfield Township, southwest of Chicago, the Will County Sheriff‚Äôs Office said in a statement on social media.

The boy was pronounced dead at a hospital. The woman had multiple stab wounds and was expected to survive, according to the statement. An autopsy on the child showed he had been stabbed dozens of times.

‚ÄúDetectives were able to determine that both victims in this brutal attack were targeted by the suspect due to them being Muslim and the on-going Middle Eastern conflict involving Hamas and the Israelis,‚Äù the sheriff‚Äôs statement said.

In recent days, police in U.S. cities and federal authorities have been on high alert for violence driven by antisemitic or Islamophobic sentiments. Jewish and Muslim groups have reported an increase of hateful and threatening rhetoric on social media.

According to the Will County sheriff‚Äôs office, the woman had called 911 to report that her landlord had attacked her with a knife, adding she then ran into a bathroom and continued to fight him off.

The man suspected in the attack was found Saturday outside the home and ‚Äúsitting upright outside on the ground near the driveway of the residence‚Äù with a cut on his forehead, authorities said.

Joseph M. Czuba of Plainfield was charged with first-degree murder, attempted first-degree murder, two counts of hate crimes and aggravated battery with a deadly weapon, according to the sheriff‚Äôs office. He was in custody Sunday and awaiting a court appearance.

By The Associated Press

Mr. Wray said on a call with reporters on Sunday that the FBI is moving quickly to mitigate the threats and that it does not discount the possibility that Hamas and other terror groups could use the conflict to call for or plot attacks in the United States.‚Å†
‚Å†
"The threat is very much ongoing and in fact, the threat picture continues to evolve," Mr. Wray said, CBS reported. "Here in the U.S., we cannot and do not discount the possibility that Hamas or other foreign terrorist organizations could exploit the conflict to call on their supporters to conduct attacks on our own soil."‚Å†
‚Å†
Speaking in an address to an international police chief conference in San Diego, California, on Saturday, Mr. Wray said the war in the Middle East is creating a "heightened environment" in the United States, where Hamas-inspired bad actors may seek to wreak havoc on home soil.‚Å†
‚Å†

If you've seen our last videos, you know that we don't have many photos in the country of Chad because photos in certain areas are frowned upon. But we wanted to share a few of our memories along with a little about what we learned about the incredible people of Chad.

First, a little info about the country. Chad is a landlocked country in Central Africa that has a deep and complex history. It's at the crossroads of the Saharan and sub-Saharan regions, and encompasses deserts, savannahs, and mountains.

The country gained independence in 1960, but its history has been marred by political instability and conflict, which continue to impact it today. Chad is currently facing daily internal conflict and security challenges. A long civil war, intermittent rebellions, and ethnic tensions have plagued the country, leading to instability and displacement of populations. The Chadian people are stuck in the middle of all this conflict.

Despite the many challenges people face, Chad is home to a resilient and diverse population known for its warmth and hospitality. The Chadian people are composed of over 200 different ethnic groups, and are known for their strong sense of community, often coming together in times of need. Despite the ongoing conflicts, they continue to strive for a better future, working towards peace, stability, and development for their nation.

Even though we didn't speak their language (there are actually 100+ different local languages spoken in Chad in addition to French!), we met so many incredibly friendly people who went out of their way to welcome us to their country.

People here have so much joy and hope despite the difficulties many of them face! So thankful to be able to meet some of these incredible people while in Chad!!

text:
Hamas claimed on Monday that Israel had not fully resumed water supplies to the Gaza Strip, despite earlier commitments to do so. An Israeli official responded by stating that some water was being provided to an area in the southern part of the enclave.

The cessation of water supply to Gaza was part of a broader siege imposed by Israel to restrict the flow of food and fuel into the region, which has a population of 2.3 million, many of whom rely on humanitarian aid. This move followed a surprise offensive by Hamas on October 7 that resulted in the deaths of 1,300 Israelis, according to officials.

In response to this attack, Israel launched a sustained bombing campaign in the Gaza Strip, resulting in significant casualties. The Gaza health ministry reported that the death toll from Israeli strikes had risen to approximately 2,750, with around 9,700 people injured. Moreover, the conflict has led to the displacement of approximately 600,000 Gazans, and essential supplies are dwindling.

'I‚Äôm not so much worried about myself, but I feel the pain of all the people of this land. People often ask me where I find hope in this situation. It‚Äôs a really difficult but important question.‚Å†

'Our Christian faith tells us that when we look at a situation of conflict like this, we cannot make simple and superficial judgments, categorising people as ‚Äògoodies‚Äô and ‚Äòbaddies‚Äô. It‚Äôs not that straightforward, as much as some people may like it to be.‚Å†
‚Å†
'Of course some people have done wicked, despicable things and that has to be acknowledged and contended with. But the vast majority of people here in Israel and Palestine don‚Äôt want that, they don‚Äôt believe in that way.'‚Å†

We invite you to read a poignant message from our Festival Director Nehad Khader written in 2021, "Narrative is Everything.‚Äù The blog post, featuring a collection of Palestinian films screened at BlackStar and elsewhere, reminds us of how history impacts the present day and the importance of creating space to tell our stories in a world that often tries to silence them.‚Å†

‚ÄúWe are building on a language that‚Äôs been co-created by generations of Palestinian, Indigenous, Black, and anti-colonial resistance movements around the world... Palestinian stories create space for us to love each other, to love ourselves, to love our cause. They document the history of my people‚Äôs freedom struggle. Palestinian stories also do something more radical: they help us think both more broadly and deeply about racism, incarceration, resistance, resource theft, apartheid, and even climate change.‚Äù - Nehad Khader
‚Å†
From AMBULANCE (2016), a raw, first-person account of the last war in Gaza, to IN VITRO (2019, pictured above), a narrative short set in the aftermath of an eco-disaster in Bethlehem. ‚Å†
‚Å†
We also invite you to watch two films that screened at recent BlackStar Film Festivals, NIGHT (2021), a short narrative about a storyteller that must trick the mother of the missing child into sleeping to save her soul, and FORAGERS (2022), a feature that combines documentary footage and fiction to depict the conflict between Israeli Nature Protection Authority and Palestinian foragers.‚Å†
‚Å†

The first image is of Wadea al Fayoume, a beautiful Palestinian American boy dressed in a red checked shirt wearing a plastic hat that reads happy birthday. It was taken a few weeks ago when he turned 6. 

The second image is a mugshot of Joseph M Czuba, the 71 year old landlord who stabbed Wadea and his mother in their home in Illinois yesterday. She survived but is in serious condition. He died from his injuries. 

Officers have enough evidence to charge Czuba with a hate crime and announce that he targeted Wadea and his mother "for being Muslim and the ongoing Middle Eastern conflict involving Hamas and Israelis".

Over the last few days, Jews have been reaching out to me because they say they feel scared. And I get it. Situations like this always cause a rise in Antisemitism. BUT IT WORKS BOTH WAYS. Situations like this always cause a rise in Islamophobia too. 

And the first child to die on US/UK soil since the war started is a Palestinian one. I encourage all my Jewish friends to take a long hard look at this photograph and remember his name the next time you feel scared and use that as a means to justify your Zionism.

Also, do not ever forget who colonised Palestine in the late 19th/early 20th century. Do not ever forget who gave the land (like it was theirs to give) to make way for an Israeli state. Do not ever forget which countries profit the most from the sales of arms and who are invested in maintaining a "strong friendship" with a country in the Middle East to suit its own needs. 

And most of all do not forget the role we all play in encouraging despicable human beings like Czuba to murder innocent children in order to make himself feel better. I hope he gets everything that's coming to him. 

Ps. We all know how Meta are suppressing posts that include certain terms but I refuse to be cowed by that. This is my account and I say what I believe needs to be said. Joseph Czuba, a 71-year-old Illinois man, was charged with hate crimes for fatally stabbing a 6-year-old Muslim boy, Wadea Al-Fayoume, and injuring his mother, Hanaan Shahin. 

The attack, driven by religious animosity and linked to the Israel-Hamas conflict, occurred in Plainfield Township, about 40 miles southwest of Chicago. 

The boy sustained 26 stab wounds from a military-style knife with a 7-inch serrated blade, while his 32-year-old mother suffered multiple stab wounds but is expected to survive.

President Joe Biden condemned the act, emphasising that the victims, Palestinian Muslims, sought refuge in America for peace and security. Czuba faces charges of first-degree murder, attempted first-degree murder, two hate crime counts, and aggravated battery with a deadly weapon.

The Will County Sheriff's Office confirmed that both victims were targeted due to their Muslim faith and the ongoing Middle Eastern conflict. Czuba, exercising his constitutional right, did not provide statements during police interviews.

The Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR) identified the victims and urged an end to Islamophobic rhetoric and anti-Palestinian racism. FBI Director Christopher Wray cautioned vigilance against increasing threats, especially from potential lone actors influenced by recent events. He emphasised the need to be watchful in this heightened environment.

Beatrice Elachi, MP for Dagoretti North, has expressed concern about the country's fuel price challenges and the impact on the economy.

Referencing the Kenya Kwanza Government's pledge to address fuel prices upon taking office, the MP demanded a return to the negotiating table, but he also raised concerns about the status of that promise.

‚ÄúCan we do fuel with Ghana because they also have fuel? Can we think of other countries we can work with? It‚Äôs like we‚Äôre tied into situation and very soon we shall be told that even the Israel-Palestine conflict can cause disruptions,‚Äù she posed on Citizen TV‚ÄôS Daybreak show early Monday.

She raised concerns that Kenya's reliance on specific fuel sources could lead to disruptions.

The legislator emphasized the importance of watching how neighboring countries such as Tanzania and Uganda manage their fuel prices, implying that Kenyans may not see a decrease in fuel prices in the near future.

‚ÄúWe have to rethink as a country because we don‚Äôt know how high the price of fuel will go and if it will ever drop,‚Äù she posited.

Larisa Shepitko was only 25 years old when she produced HEAT (1963), her astonishingly assured debut feature, based on a short story by young writer Chinghiz Aitmatov about the conflict between idealistic teenager Kemel and the domineering, tyrannical Abakir, living and working side-by-side in the same Kyrgyzstan collective. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Playing at Metrograph starting October 20th as part of our series, First & Last, in which we bring together early and late works by a bevy of world-class filmmakers.

Posted @withregram ‚Ä¢ @patrickteahantherapy A healthy family talks it over and works it out.‚Å†
‚Å†
There are families like this out there, and the parents model:‚Å†
‚Å†
*Conflict resolution between siblings‚Å†
*Good communication around everything from boundaries to logistics‚Å†
*Healthy intimacy and mutual respect between parents‚Å†
*Empathy and understanding during bumps‚Å†
‚Å†
A toxic family system for lack of resources and willingness to use them if present will engage in the following:‚Å†
‚Å†
*Distracting from more significant family issues by scapegoating a member‚Å†
*Cultivates contempt vs. empathy and respect‚Å†
*Minimizes unfair issues, and conflict due to emotional laziness (cowardice)‚Å†
*Conditions members to believe that conflict is selfish, and we are left to believe it isn't worth it (because it isn't growing up)‚Å†
*Believes that not bringing issues up is a morally good thing‚Å†
‚Å†
As we grow and heal from childhood trauma, we need to try to have faith in healthy conflict while finishing business with our family's toxicity around intimacy, respect, and connection.‚Å†
‚Å†

In an open letter to his friend Cardinal Dominik Duka, published October 13 exclusively by Settimo Cielo, Cardinal Gerhard Ludwig M√ºller criticizes in depth the response given last September 25 by Cardinal Victor Manuel Fern√°ndez, the new prefect of the Dicastery for the Doctrine of the Faith, to a series of questions from Duka himself regarding Eucharistic communion for the divorced and ‚Äúremarried.‚Äù

Duka, archbishop emeritus of Prague, forwarded these questions last July, on behalf of the Czech episcopal conference, to the dicastery headed by Cardinal Fern√°ndez, who had in none other than Cardinal M√ºller his penultimate predecessor, abruptly dismissed in 2017 by Pope Francis, with whom Fern√°ndez is, instead, bosom buddies.

But before reading M√ºller‚Äôs letter, it is helpful to go back over what led up to the dramatic conflict.

Last October 4, in the opening speech of the Synod on Synodality, Francis went at it with ‚Äúthe pressure of public opinion‚Äù that, ‚Äúwhen there was the Synod on the Family,‚Äù wanted to have it believed ‚Äúthat Communion was going to be given to the divorced.‚Äù

But he failed to mention that none other than he, the Pope, in February of 2014, a few months before the opening of that synod, had convened a two-day consistory behind closed doors among all the cardinals, obliging them to discuss an introductory talk by Cardinal Walter Kasper fully in support of Communion for the divorced and ‚Äúremarried.‚Äù

Read more at link in bio.

An incident occurred in Plainfield, Illinois, where a man named Joseph Czuba, aged 71, has been charged with murder and hate crimes. He allegedly stabbed to death a six-year-old boy, Wadea Al-Fayoume, who was Muslim, and seriously wounded the boy's mother. Both victims were tenants of Czuba, who reportedly targeted them because of their religion and the ongoing conflict between Hamas and Israel. The attack took place in their rented residence.

The 32-year-old mother was attacked with a military-style knife and managed to call the police from the bathroom. She sustained more than a dozen stab wounds but is expected to survive. Tragically, her son, Wadea Al-Fayoume, aged six, was stabbed over two dozen times and later died in the hospital.

More: When authorities arrived at the scene, they found Joseph Czuba outside the property with a cut on his face. He was taken to the hospital for treatment before being charged with first-degree murder, attempted first-degree murder, hate crimes, and aggravated battery. While he did not provide a statement, investigators identified his motive as targeting the victims due to their Muslim faith and their connection to the Middle Eastern conflict between Hamas and Israelis.
The U.S. Justice Department has initiated a federal hate crime investigation into this case.

The history of Armenians in Nagorno-Karabakh ended in the old manner of conflict resolution: siege and expulsion. For Armenians, a classic relic ethnic minority whose Christianity and peculiar alphabet date to the epic struggles between the Romans and the Parthians, it was another Genocide.

Additionally, this conflict is being considered by many worldwide to be a clash of civilizations. Instead, in its emboldening of traditional regional powers like Turkey, scrambling for geopolitical spoils after the retreat of superpowers, it's a harbinger of the coming world disorder.
___________________________________________________

In an op-ed, U.S. Senator Gary Peters of Michigan writes that Armenians in Nagorno-Karabakh face an existential threat ‚Äî and the United States must come to their aid.

The U.S. must help ensure that the people of Nagorno-Karabakh receive the humanitarian assistance they desperately need. Critically ‚Äî given the history of this region ‚Äî the United States must do everything it can to bring in neutral observers to shine a light on the conditions the Azerbaijani government has created.

Oil and gas exploration company ReconAfrica has so far drilled and installed 36 solar-powered water wells in the Kavango East and Kavango West regions at the tune of N$21 million. This includes 10 additional community water wells handed over on Saturday, with both regions receiving five additional boreholes each.

During the handover at Tjeya village, Sambyu Traditional Authority hompa Sophia Mundjembe applauded the company for the gesture, saying that bringing potable water closer to the people at Tjeye will reduce human-wildlife conflict. She said people will have access to clean, healthy water, eliminating the need to go to the river to collect water for household use.

Kapembe village headman Oiva Muronga said people will no longer have to travel long distances to collect water after the village has gone without potable water since it was established 27 years ago.

Complaint filed against Rizwan in India for offering prayer on the field

A complaint has been filed by an Indian lawyer with the International Cricket Council against Mohammad Rizwan for offering prayer on the field and dedicating Pakistan's victory over Sri Lanka to the people of Gaza, Times Now reported.

Rizwan scored a match-winning century against Sri Lanka, which he dedicated to the people of Gaza in light of the ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict.

Vineet Jindal, an advocate of Supreme Court of India lodged a complaint

with the ICC against the Pakistani cricketer.

"This is a complaint about Pakistan Cricket Player, Mohammad Rizwan, who was seen offering namaz on the cricket field during his team's opening match of the ongoing ICC Men's ODI World Cup 2023 on Friday (October 6) against the Netherlands in Hyderabad," the complaint read.

Jindal went on to add that Rizwan offering prayer on the cricket field amid many Indians was symbolic of the intentional depiction of his religion which stands against the spirit of the game.

"This very act of the player raises questions about the spirit of the match and raises a question of the ideology, the player follows while playing the match. The act of displaying his religion by Mohammed Rizwan purposefully depicts his intent to message that he is a Muslim, defeating the spirit of sports," he said.

Rizwan was seen offering prayers amid the field while his teammates were waiting for the drinks during the break, he added.

For him, the Pakistani wicket-keeping batter's statement in his press conference regarding the dedication of his victory to the people of Gaza further attested to his religious and political ideology.

NEWS | This past week, Cornellians gathered for vigils on Ho Plaza to mourn the loss of Israeli and Palestinian lives in the Israel-Hamas War, which has resulted in the deaths of over 2,300 Palestinians and 1,300 Israelis. 

On Wednesday, Oct. 11, when classes resumed after Fall Break, Cornell Hillel and Cornellians for Israel hosted a candlelight vigil to commemorate the Israeli lives lost in Hamas‚Äôs initial attack on Israel on Saturday, Oct. 7. Approximately 750 Cornell students, faculty and staff attended the vigil to listen to stories of those affected by the conflict.

Molly Goldstein ‚Äô25, co-president of the Cornell Center for Jewish Living, expressed hope that the vigil would inspire the Cornell community to condemn violence and join together during a period of immense suffering. 
‚ÄúWhat I hope to see most is that people condemn violence. There are civilians on both sides who are living in the worst nightmare they could have possibly imagined,‚Äù Goldstein said. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôd hope that the Cornell community wants peace, and wants harmony, and hopes that the violence and the terrorism will end.‚Äù

On Friday, Oct. 14, around 200 students, faculty and community members gathered on Ho Plaza for a vigil held by Students for Justice in Palestine, after a collective moment of silence in honor of those killed in the conflict. The vigil came mere hours after the Israel Ministry of Defense and the Israel Defense Forces issued a directive calling for the evacuation of over one million Palestinians residing in the northern region of Gaza. 

As students processed these events and their anger with Cornell‚Äôs response to the war which did not mention the word Palestine, some, like SJP member Maryam Ismail ‚Äô27, found comfort in the vigil.

‚ÄúThis was a really safe space for people to talk about how they‚Äôre feeling and grieve openly, and I think it‚Äôs beautiful that people from all different backgrounds came to support each other,‚Äù Ismail said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important, it‚Äôs healing and it established a community that people didn‚Äôt even think existed here.‚Äù

Writer Louise Gl√ºck died on Oct 13, 2023. The personal, the mythological, and the Biblical are woven intricately throughout Gl√ºck‚Äôs oeuvre. 

Major themes in Gl√ºck‚Äôs writing include motherhood, family conflict, marriage, separation, intimacy, the body, death, grief, and nature. An Unexpected Path, by Megan McSpadden
Pub Date: November 17 

‚ÄúSometimes unexpected paths lead to the best destinations.‚Äù

The perfect fall romance is nearly here! 

I am thrilled to be an early reader for An Unexpected Path! Megan‚Äôs DEBUT novel is a knock out. An avid reader herself, Megan pulled the best parts from contemporary romance to create a novel that was charming, endearing and unputdownable! 

Forced proximity; 
a few mishaps which had me laughing and maybe cringing in the best possible way; 
quirky neighbours and side characters; 
reticence paired with longing; heartbreak, hope and resilience. 
Oh, and 21 puppies . Give or take. 

I really loved the ease of Meg‚Äôs writing. Her pacing was pitch perfect and her story building was all at once relatable while also having me want go on a hike just to sprain my ankle! 
#iykyk and if not, read the book and you‚Äôll soon understand - trust me! 

Get those Kindles ready!!

Synopsis: 
Highly sought after conflict photographer, relationship-averse Marley Cunningham thrives on adrenaline and the chaos of her nomadic life. But when the passion for her career starts to wane, she decides a hike is the best way to shake the doubts from her mind. Spraining her ankle and being rescued by a handsome stranger and his pack of dogs is not part of the plan.
Big-hearted, reclusive Bennett Morgan has spent his life playing football then pursuing medicine. After a catastrophic diagnosis shatters both goals he feels lost for the first time He packs up his life and two dogs and returns to the home. He finds joy in starting a dog sanctuary.
After a rainstorm washes away the road to Bennett‚Äôs home, he is shocked to find Marley injured and alone on his secluded trail. From the moment she is hoisted onto his back, Marley is drawn in by Bennett‚Äôs kindness, strength and calm nature. Bennett realizes that a bit more human connection in his life might not be such a bad thing, especially when that human is Marley.
Marley begins to explore her feelings for not just her career but the man who rescued her.
